IRS will not contact taxpayers by email, text message (including short links), phone or social media channels to request or verify personal or financial information. This includes requesting personal identification number (PIN), password or credit card, or other financial account information. Visit the IRS IdentityTheft Center web page at IRS.gov/IdentityTheft to get information about identity theft and data security protection for taxpayers, tax professionals and businesses. If your SSN is lost or stolen, or you suspect you are a victim of tax-related identity theft, you can learn what actions you should take.

U.S. tax payments must be made in U.S. dollars to the IRS. We do not accept digital assets. Visit IRS.gov/Payments to learn about using any of the following methods to make a payment. IRS Direct Pay (Direct Pay): Pay your personal tax bill or estimated tax by check or savings account without any fees. Debit card, credit card, or digital wallet: Choose an approved payment processor and pay online or by phone. Electronic Funds Withdrawal (EFW): Set up a payment when filing your federal tax return using tax software or through a tax professional. Electronic Federal Tax Payment System (EFTPS): This is the best option for businesses. You must register. Check or money order: Mail your payment to the address listed in the notice or instructions. Cash: You can pay your tax bill in cash at a retail store where you file your tax return. Wire Transfer: You can make a same-day wire transfer from a financial institution. Contact your financial institution to determine availability, fees, and timeframes.

Please visit IRS.gov/Payments to get more information about your choice. If you can't pay your taxes in full today, you can apply for an Online Payment Agreement (IRS.gov/OPA) to pay your tax bill over time. After you complete the online process, you will immediately receive a notice telling you whether your agreement has been approved. Use the Compromise Offer in Lieu of Payment (English) to see if you can pay less than the amount you owe in taxes. For more information about the Compromise Offer in Lieu of Payment program, visit IRS.gov/OIC.

You may request a change of language preference by using Form LEP (1040 Schedule), which is available at irs.gov/forms. You may not immediately receive the communication in the language you requested. The IRS commitment to provide translations for LEP taxpayers is part of a multi-year plan to translate communications, including English notifications and correspondence, beginning in 2023. You will continue to receive communications, including English notifications and correspondence, until they are translated into your preferred language.

TAS can help you resolve problems you can't solve on your own with the IRS. Be sure to try to solve your problem with the IRS first, but if you can't, go to TAS. Our service is free. TAS helps all taxpayers (and their representatives), including individuals, businesses, and tax-exempt organizations. If your IRS problem results in financial difficulty, if you have tried but cannot solve your problem with the IRS, or if you think the IRS system, processes, or procedures are not working properly, you may be eligible for TAS assistance. To get help with general tax topics at any time, visit www.TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov (English). That website can help you with common tax problems and situations, such as what to do if you made a mistake on your tax return or if you received a notice from the IRS. TAS is committed to solving large-scale (systemic) problems that affect many taxpayers. You can report system problems at www.IRS.gov/SAMS. (Please do not include any personal identifying information.)

This publication provides general information about federal tax laws that apply to self-employed individuals and statutory employees. It contains information about business income, business expenses, and tax deductions that can help small business owners prepare their income tax returns.

If you and your spouse jointly own and operate a non-legal business and share profits, you are partners in the partnership regardless of whether you have a formal partnership agreement. Do not use Schedule C. File Form 1065, U.S. Partnership Return of Income. For more information, see Publication 541, Partnerships. Exception - Joint Income. If you and your spouse own as community property under the community property laws of a state, foreign country, or U.S. territory a non-legal business, you may treat the business as a sole proprietorship or a partnership. States that have community property laws include Arizona, California, Idaho, Louisiana, Nevada, New Mexico, Texas, Washington, and Wisconsin. A change in your filing status will be treated as a change in the entity. See Publication 555 for more information about community property laws. Exception - Qualified Joint Venture (QJV). If you and your spouse are the only members of a business that you jointly own and operate and you are substantially involved in the business and you file a joint return for the tax year, you may elect to treat the business as a QJV instead of a partnership for that tax year. This option allows you to avoid the complexity of Form 1065 while still allowing your spouse to receive Social Security credits based on the number of Social Security points earned. For the definition of substantially involved, see the instructions for Schedule G (Form 1040), line G. This option is only available for a business that is owned and operated by your spouse as a community property owner (not as a legal entity under state law). Therefore, a business owned and operated by your spouse through an LLC does not qualify for the QJV option.

If you need more information, see Form 8886 instructions or Abuse of Tax Shelters and Transactions (English). Small Business and Self-Employed Tax Center. Do you need help with tax problems or filing forms? Or do you need free publications or forms? The SB/SE Tax Center serves filers of Form 1040, Form 1040-SR, Schedule C, Schedule E or Schedule F, or Form 2106. For more information, visit the SB/SE Tax Center at IRS.gov/Businesses/Small. The Gig Economy Tax Center. The gig economy (also known as the on-demand, sharing, or access economy) refers to the range of activities people engage in to earn income by providing on-demand work, services, or goods. Visit IRS.gov/Gig to learn more about the tax consequences of participating in the gig economy.

After you calculate your gross income and gross expenses, you can calculate your business's net profit or net loss. You can subtract gross expenses from gross income to calculate net profit or net loss. If your expenses are less than your income, the difference is net profit and is included as part of line 3 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040). If your expenses are more than your income, the difference is net loss. You usually can deduct net loss from line 3 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040) total income. However, in some cases, your loss is limited. This chapter briefly describes three of those situations. Other possible limitations on your loss are explained in the instructions for Schedule C, lines G and 32.

Your trade or business losses may be limited. If you have a loss, use Form 461 to determine the amount of your excess business loss. Your excess business loss will be reported as income on Schedule 1 (Form 1040) line 8p and is considered a net operating loss (NOL), which you must carry forward and deduct in the following year. For more information about the limits on excess business losses, see Form 461 and its instructions.

If your purpose in engaging in business is not for profit, then you may be limited in the amount of deduction you can claim. You cannot offset losses from other income. Your hobbies or main sports or entertainment activities are subject to this limitation. For more information about non-profit activities, see Hobby or Business: What You Need to Know.

Generally, under the same rules applicable to U.S. citizens, tax law defines residents who must pay self-employment tax. Non-tax law residents do not have to pay self-employment tax unless an effective Social Security Agreement (also called Totalization Agreement) determines that they are covered by the U.S. Social Security system. However, residents of the U.S. Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico, Guam, the Northern Mariana Islands, or American Samoa are required to pay self-employment tax because they are considered U.S. residents for self-employment tax purposes. For more information about foreigners, see Publication 519, Foreign Tax Guide.

If any income from trade or business (other than a partnership) is income that is subject to state community property laws, that income should be included in the spouse who engages in the trade or business in determining the self-employment tax to be paid by that spouse.

Do not include in self-employment income any income or loss from the disposition of property held mainly for sale to customers, whether or not the property is inventory. It does not matter whether the disposition is a sale, exchange, or involuntary conversion.

If you are self-employed and you reduce or stop your business activity, you should include in your self-employment income any amounts you receive from insurance or other sources to compensate for business income lost. If you are not working when you receive the payment, the payment is still related to your business and should be included in your self-employment income, even if your business is temporarily inactive.

If you are employed by a church or a qualified church-controlled organization (pastors, religious group members, and Christian Science practitioners are excluded) and you receive $108.28 or more in compensation from the church or organization, you must pay self-employment tax. For more information, see Publication 517, Church Employee's and Minister's Social Security and Other Information.

If you are a crew member of a vessel that catches fish or other aquatic life and you meet all of the following conditions, your income is subject to self-employment tax. 1. You do not receive any compensation for your work other than your share of the catch or the proceeds from the sale of the catch, unless the compensation meets all of the following conditions. 1. The compensation for each trip does not exceed $100. 2. The compensation is only paid when the minimum catch is reached. 3. The compensation is used only to pay for other duties (such as the first mate, engineer, or cook), and in the fishing industry, additional cash compensation is a traditional practice. 2. You will receive a share of the catch or the proceeds from the sale of the catch. 3. Your share depends on the catch. 4. The vessel's crew is typically less than 10 people. (If the average number of crew members for all trips during the past four calendar quarters was less than 10, the crew is typically considered to be less than 10 people.)
If you are an employee of a state or local government and are compensated only on a fee basis and are not covered by the federal-state Social Security agreement, you must pay self-employment taxes.

If both of the following conditions are true, you must pay self-employment tax. 1. You are a U.S. citizen employed by a foreign government, a foreign government's wholly owned entity, or an international organization in the United States, Puerto Rico, Guam, the U.S. Virgin Islands, American Samoa, or the Northern Mariana Islands. 2. Your employer does not withhold Social Security and Medicare taxes from your wages.

If you are a self-employed U.S. citizen or resident as defined by the tax code, in most cases you must pay self-employment tax. In calculating self-employment tax, your self-employed foreign income cannot be reduced by the foreign income exemption portion.

When you have a loss or a small net income and any of the following situations apply, you may want to use the optional method (discussed later). You want to earn Social Security benefit points. You incur child or dependent care expenses that qualify for a deduction (optional method may increase your income and thus your deduction). You are entitled to the Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC) (optional method may increase your income and thus your deduction). You are entitled to the Additional Child Tax Credit (ACTC) (optional method may increase your income and thus your deduction).

Using optional methods may increase your self-employment tax. Paying more self-employment tax may make you eligible for higher benefits when you retire. Because half of your self-employment tax is deducted from your AGI on Form 1040 or 1040-SR, using optional methods may also reduce your AGI, which may affect the amount of deductions, credits, or other items that are limited by your AGI. Calculate your AGI using and not using the optional methods to determine whether the optional methods are advantageous for you. If you use either or both of these methods, you must calculate and pay self-employment tax based on these methods, even if you could pay less tax or no tax using the regular method. Optional methods may be used only to calculate your self-employment tax. To calculate your income tax, include your actual income in your total income, regardless of which method you use to determine your self-employment tax.

Only use the non-farm optional method for non-farm income. If you meet all of the following tests, you can use this method. 1. You are a continuous self-employed individual. This means that, in the 3 tax years before you use this method, you had net self-employment income of $400 or more. For this purpose, the net income for the previous year can come from farm or non-farm income or both. 2. You use this method for less than 5 years. (There is a 5-year use limit.) The years do not have to be consecutive. 3. Your non-farm net profit is: 1. less than $7,493, and 2. less than 72.189% of your total non-farm income.
Your nonfarm total income is usually the sum of the following amounts: Line 7 of Schedule C (Form 1040); and Box 14, code C (from nonfarm partnership businesses) of Schedule K-1 (Form 1065).
The following example shows how to calculate net income when non-farm gross income is less than $10,380.
The following examples illustrate how to calculate net income when nonfarm total income exceeds $10,380.

Use Schedule SE (Form 1040) to calculate and report your self-employment taxes. If you file Form 1040 or 1040-SR, enter your self-employment taxes on Schedule 2, line 4, and attach Schedule SE to your return. If you file Form 1040-SS, enter your SE tax on line 3 and attach Schedule SE to your return. If you must pay self-employment taxes, you must file Form 1040, 1040-SR, or 1040-SS (with Schedule SE) even if you don't have to file a federal income tax return.

We accept most tax returns filed by taxpayers. If we ask about your tax return or select it for review, it does not mean that you are dishonest. Asking or reviewing does not necessarily result in an increase in your tax. We may close your case without change or you may receive a refund. The process of selecting a tax return for review usually begins in one of two ways. One way is that we use computer programs to identify tax returns that may have amounts that are incorrect. These programs may be based on tax return information (such as forms 1099 and W-2); past review research, or other special items determined issues. Another way is to use information from compliance sources that indicate that amounts in the tax return may be incorrect. These sources may include newspapers, public records, and individuals. If we determine that the information is accurate and reliable, we may use it to select a tax return for review. Publication 556, Tax Return Examinations, Claims and Refunds, explains the rules and procedures we follow in our examinations. The following chapters give an overview of how we conduct examinations.

If you disagree with the reviewer's proposed changes, you can appeal to the Internal Revenue Service Independent Office of Appeals. Most disputes can be resolved without expensive and time-consuming court trials. Your right to appeal is explained in Publication 5, Your Right to Appeal and How to Prepare a Protest, and Publication 556, Your Right to Appeal and How to Prepare a Protest. If you do not wish to use the Office of Appeals or disagree with its findings, you can take your case to the United States Tax Court, the United States Court of Federal Claims, or the United States District Court in the district where you live. If you take your case to court, the IRS will have the burden of proving certain facts. If the court agrees with you on most of the issues in your case and finds that our position is largely unreasonable, you may be able to get some of your administrative and litigation costs back. Unless you try to resolve your case through the administrative process, including the appeals system, and you provide us with the information needed to resolve your case, you will not be eligible for this reimbursement.

Generally, you and your spouse are jointly and separately liable for all taxes, interest, or penalties due on your joint return. To seek relief from any obligations related to your spouse (or former spouse), you must file Form 8857, Request for Innocent Spouse Relief. In some cases, Form 8857 may need to be filed within 2 years of the first date the IRS attempts to collect taxes from you. Do not file Form 8857 with Form 1040 or 1040-SR. For more information, see Publication 971, Innocent Spouse Relief, and Form 8857, or call the Innocent Spouse Office toll-free at 855-851-2009.

通常，國稅局會直接與您或您的正式授權代表交涉。但是，如果我們需要您無法提供的資訊或驗證我們獲得的資訊，我們有時會與其他人交談。如果我們確實聯絡了其他人，例如鄰居、銀行、雇主或僱員，我們通常需要告訴他們有限的資訊，例如您的姓名。法律禁止我們披露任何超出獲取或驗證我們正在尋求的資訊所必需的資訊。只要您的案件需要進行其他行動，我們就可能會繼續聯絡其他人。如果我們確實聯絡了其他人，您有權索取聯絡人員的名單。您可以透過電話、書面或個人面談提出您的請求。

If you think you have paid too much tax, you can claim a refund. You usually have to claim a refund within 3 years of the date you filed your original return or 2 years of the date you paid the tax (whichever is later). For more information about refunds, see Publication 556. If you are entitled to a refund but did not file a return, you must file a refund claim within 2 years after you paid the tax. The law generally provides that if a refund is not paid to you within 45 days of the date you filed your return or claimed a refund, interest will be charged on the refund.

After you receive all your wage and income statements (W-2, W-2G, 1099-R, 1099-MISC, 1099-NEC, etc.), unemployment compensation statements (mailed or electronic format), other government payment statements (form 1099-G), and interest, dividends, and retirement income statements (form 1099), you have several choices for filing and submitting your tax return. You can file your own tax return, check to see if you qualify for free tax preparation services, or hire a tax professional to prepare your tax return for you.

Taxpayers who need information about accessible services can call 833-690-0598. The accessible help line can answer questions about current and future accessible products and services provided in alternative media formats (such as braille, large print, audio, etc.). The accessible services help line does not have access to your IRS account. If you need help with tax laws, refunds or account-related issues, visit IRS.gov/LetUsHelp.

Through your online account, you can access a variety of information to help you during tax season. You can obtain copies, view recently filed tax returns, and get adjusted gross income. Go to IRS.gov/Account to set up or access your online account.

The safest and easiest way to get your refund is to file electronically and choose direct deposit. This way, you can safely deposit your refund directly into your financial account electronically. Direct deposit also avoids the possibility of lost, stolen, damaged, or undeliverable checks to the IRS. Eight out of ten taxpayers use direct deposit to get their refund. If you don't have a bank account, go to IRS.gov/DirectDeposit to find out where to find a bank or credit union that offers online accounts.

The IRS will not contact taxpayers via email, text message (including short links), phone or social media to request or verify personal or financial information. This includes requests for personal identification numbers (PINs), passwords or similar information for credit cards, bank accounts or other financial accounts. Visit IRS.gov/IdentityTheft, the IRS Identity Theft Center webpage, to learn about identity theft and data security for taxpayers, tax professionals and businesses. If your Social Security number is lost or stolen, or you suspect you are a victim of tax-related identity theft, you can learn what steps to take. Obtain a set of Identity Protection Personal Identification Numbers (IP PINs). Identity Protection PINs are six-digit numbers assigned to taxpayers to help prevent their Social Security numbers from being used in fraud to file federal income tax returns. When you have an Identity Protection PIN, you can prevent others from using your Social Security number to file a tax return. For more information, visit IRS.gov/IPPIN.

U.S. tax payments must be made in U.S. dollars to the IRS. We do not accept digital assets. Visit IRS.gov/Payments to learn about using any of the following methods to make a payment. IRS Direct Pay: Pay your personal tax bill or estimated tax from your check or savings account directly, and without additional fees. Debit card, credit card, or digital wallet: Choose an approved payment processor and pay online or by phone. Electronic Funds Transfer (EFT): Provide instructions to pay when using tax software or through a tax professional to file your federal tax return. Federal Tax Electronic Payment System (EFTPS): This is the best option for businesses. You must register. Check or money order: Mail your payment to the address listed on your notice or explanation. Cash: You can pay your taxes in cash at participating retail stores. Wire transfer: You may be able to make a same-day wire transfer from your financial institution. Contact your financial institution to learn about feasibility, fees, and timeframes.

Please visit IRS.gov/Payments to learn more about your options. Apply for an Online Payment Agreement (IRS.gov/OPA) to pay your tax bill in monthly installments (if you can't pay your tax bill in full today). After you complete the online process, you will immediately receive a notice telling you whether your agreement has been approved. Use the Online Offer in Compromise (OIC) Pre-Screening Tool (English) to determine if you may be eligible to settle your tax debt for less than the amount you owe. For more information about the OIC program, visit IRS.gov/OIC.

You may request a change of language preference by using Form LEP (1040 Schedule), which is available at irs.gov/forms. You may not immediately receive the communication in the language you requested. The IRS commitment to provide translations for LEP taxpayers is part of a multi-year plan to translate communications, including English notifications and correspondence, beginning in 2023. You will continue to receive communications, including English notifications and correspondence, until they are translated into your preferred language.

TAS can help you resolve problems you can't solve on your own with the IRS. Be sure to try to solve your problem with the IRS first, but if you can't, go to TAS. Our service is free. TAS helps all taxpayers (and their representatives), including individuals, businesses, and tax-exempt organizations. If your IRS problem results in financial difficulty, if you have tried but cannot solve your problem with the IRS, or if you think the IRS system, processes, or procedures are not working properly, you may be eligible for TAS assistance. To get help with general tax topics at any time, visit www.TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov (English). That website can help you with common tax problems and situations, such as what to do if you made a mistake on your tax return or if you received a notice from the IRS. TAS is committed to solving large-scale (systemic) problems that affect many taxpayers. You can report system problems at www.IRS.gov/SAMS. (Please do not include any personal identifying information.)

The Small Business Administration (SBA) provides training and educational programs, business counseling, financial planning, and contract assistance to small business owners. The SBA also provides publications and videos on a variety of business topics. The following is a brief description of the assistance provided by the SBA.
You can visit the SBA website: SBA.gov (English). When you visit the SBA website, you can find a variety of information that is of interest to small business owners.
You can seek assistance for your small business at the SBDC. To find one near you, visit the SBA website or call the SBA Help Line.

In general, you should use your SSN as your Tax Identification Number (TIN). You must write the number on every individual income tax return you file, such as Form 1040 and its schedules. To apply for an SSN, use Form SS-5, Application for a Social Security Number. You can get the form from a Social Security Administration (SSA) office or by calling 800-772-1213. You can also get the form from the SSA website at SSA.gov/forms/ss-5 (English).

If you have employees, you must obtain each employee's SSN. Keep a record of the employee's name and SSN as shown on the Social Security card. If the employee's name is incorrect on the card, the employee should request SSA to issue a new card. If the employee's name changes due to marriage or divorce, this may occur. Form W-4, Employee's Withholding Allowance Certificate, is to be completed by each employee so that the correct amount of federal income tax is withheld from the employee's pay. If an employee does not have an SSN, the employee should file Form SS-5 with SSA.

If your net self-employment income is $400 or more, you must file a 2024 income tax return. If your net self-employment income is less than $400, but you meet any other filing requirements listed in the instructions for Form 1040, you still must file an income tax return.

Paperless filing is easier than you think, and it's available to most filers who file electronically - including first-time filers 16 years of age or older by the end of 2024. If you use tax preparation software or a tax professional to file, you'll use the IRS e-file Self-Select PIN method to sign your return. If you choose to file married filing jointly, you and your spouse each need to establish a PIN and enter it as your electronic signature. To establish a PIN, you'll need to get your Adjusted Gross Income (AGI) from your original 2023 tax return (not from an amended return, Form 1040-X, or a Math Error Notice you received from the IRS). You'll also need to provide your date of birth (DOB). Make sure your DOB is correct and matches the information on your SSA record before e-filing. To do this, check your annual Social Security Statement. If you use the Self-Select PIN method, you don't need to sign or mail any paperwork - not even a W-2. For more information about the Self-Select PIN method, go to IRS.gov.

You can choose to have your refund check mailed to you, or have your refund deposited directly into your checking or savings account. Using IRS e-file, refund processing time is half that of paper filing. Most refunds are issued within 21 days.

The IRS cannot issue refunds for tax returns claiming the EITC or ACTC until mid-February 2025. This applies to the entire refund amount, not just the portion related to the tax credits.

If your tax return shows that you owe taxes, you must pay the taxes (ignoring any filing extensions) before the tax return due date to avoid paying late payment penalties and interest. For 2024, file by April 15, 2025. You have several payment options, including setting up an electronic funds withdrawal from your checking or savings account, or making a payment using a debit or credit card. For more information about payment options, go to IRS.gov/Payments.
If your AGI is $84,000 or less in 2024, you can use free tax software to file your tax return and e-file your return.

The public-private partnership between the IRS and tax software providers enables about a dozen brands of commercial tax software products and e-file to be provided to taxpayers at no cost. Visit IRS.gov/FreeFile for details. You can view the free-file standards for each software provider, or use the online tool to find out which free products are available to you. Some software providers offer free state tax filing services.

The IRS also provides electronic versions of IRS paper forms. These electronic forms can be filed electronically (e-filed) for free. Free file forms can be used by anyone who wants to file their own tax return. These forms are not limited by income. Free file forms can perform basic math. This method only supports federal tax forms.

For calendar year 2024, Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR is due by April 15, 2025. If you use fiscal year (explained in Chapter 2), your tax return is due by the 15th day of the 4th month after your fiscal year ends. If you file late, you may owe penalties and interest. If you cannot file on time, use Form 4868, Application for Automatic Extension of Time to File U.S. Individual Income Tax Return, to request an automatic 6-month extension. For calendar year taxpayers, this will extend the filing due date to October 15. Filing an extension request will not extend the time to pay your taxes, it will only extend the time to file your return.

Federal income tax is a pay-as-you-go tax. You must pay taxes on income you earn or receive during the year. Income tax for employees is usually withheld from their paychecks. If you don't have taxes withheld from your income or you don't pay enough tax this way, you may have to pay estimated tax.
Other options include deducting any overpayment of your 2023 tax return from your 2024 estimated tax payments, or mailing a check or money order with your 1040-ES payment voucher.

1. If you need to register for EFTPS, please visit EFTPS.gov (English), or call 800-555-4477. 2. When you request a new EIN, you may be automatically registered for EFTPS. 3. The benefits of EFTPS include the following: 1. Reduce the chance of errors when making payments. 2. Receive real-time confirmation of each transaction.

Self-employment tax is primarily for individuals who work for themselves. It is similar to the Social Security and Medicare taxes that are withheld from most wage earners' paychecks. If you are a statutory employee earning income, you do not have to pay self-employment taxes on that income. Social Security and Medicare taxes should be withheld from that income.

As with wage earners, self-employed individuals are eligible for social security benefits. Your self-employment tax ensures that you receive benefits within the scope of the social security system. Social Security Insurance provides you with retirement benefits, disability benefits, survivor benefits, and medical insurance benefits. Make sure to report all of your self-employed income. If you don't report all of your self-employed income, your social security benefits may be reduced when you retire.

In 2024, your income of $1,730 (2025: $1,810) per Social Security tax filing will earn you one work point (up to four work points). Therefore, if your 2024 Social Security tax filing income (self-employment income and wages) is $6,920, you will earn four work points (6,920 / 1,730). For an explanation of the points needed to qualify for Social Security benefits and the benefits available to you and your family, consult the Social Security office nearest you. Making false statements to obtain or increase Social Security benefits may result in a penalty.

Generally, the IRS will only award points for self-employment income that you report on tax returns filed within 3 years and 3 months and 15 days after the tax year in which you earned the income. If you file a tax return or report a change to your self-employment income after this deadline, the Social Security Administration may change its records, but only remove or reduce the amount. The Social Security Administration will not change its records to increase your self-employment income.

You are a self-employed individual in the tax and finance domains. You must pay a 12.4% self-employment tax on the first $168,600 of your 2024 combined wages, tips, and net income. You must also pay a 2.9% self-employment tax on all of your combined wages, tips, and net income. If you are an employee and receive wages and tips that are subject to Social Security or Railroad Retirement Tax (RRT) Grade 1 or both, and the total is at least $168,600, you do not have to pay the 12.4% self-employment tax on any of your net income. However, you must pay the 2.9% self-employment tax on all of your net income. On line 15 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040), deduct half of the self-employment tax as an income adjustment.

If you have both salary and self-employment income, the highest amount of self-employment income tax that you must pay will be reduced by the amount of your salary (but not less than zero). Use form 8959 - Additional Medicare Tax to calculate the tax.

You must file a W-2 form to report income you received from your employer, such as wages, tips, and other compensation; and income tax withheld, Social Security tax, and Medicare tax. You can file a W-2 form online. For more information about W-2 forms, see General Information About Form W-2 and Form W-3.

If you receive more than $10,000 in cash in one transaction or in two or more related business transactions, you must file a 8300 form (Report of Cash Payments of More Than $10,000 Made to or for a Single Person or for a Business). Cash includes U.S. and foreign currency. Cash also includes certain financial instruments, such as bank notes, travelers checks, and money orders. Cash does not include checks drawn from a person's personal account (personal checks). For more information, see Publication 1544, Report of Cash Payments of More Than $10,000 Made to or for a Single Person or for a Business.

If you do not file Form 8300, file a false or fraudulent Form 8300, or structure a transaction to avoid reporting requirements, you may be subject to civil and criminal penalties, including imprisonment of up to 5 years.

You must calculate your taxable income and file an income tax return for the tax year. Similarly, you must consistently use a clear accounting method that reflects your income and expenses for the tax year.

If you filed your first income tax return using the calendar year tax year, and subsequently operate as a sole proprietor, you must continue to use the calendar year, unless you obtain IRS approval to change or are allowed to change without IRS approval. For more information, see Change Tax Year. If you use the calendar year tax year, you must keep books and records, and report income and expenses for the period from January 1 through December 31 each year.

A fiscal year is any 12-month period ending on the last day of any month other than December. A 52- to 53-week fiscal year is a fiscal year that is 52 to 53 weeks long but does not end on the last day of a month. If you use a fiscal year, you must keep books and records and use the same fiscal year to report income and expenses. If you want to know more about fiscal years, including 52- to 53-week fiscal years, see Publication 538.

Accounting methods are a set of rules that determine when and how to report income and expenses. Your accounting method includes not only the complete accounting method you use, but also the accounting treatment you use for any significant items. When you file your first income tax return (including the Schedule C for your business), you choose an accounting method for your business. If you later want to change your accounting method, you usually must get IRS approval. See Change of Accounting Method.
You must use the same accounting method to calculate your taxable income and to record it. Similarly, you must use an accounting method that clearly reflects your income.

You can use different accounting methods to handle business and personal items. For example, even if you use cash accounting for your personal items, you can use accrual accounting for your business income.

If you have two or more separate and distinct businesses, you can use different accounting methods for each business if the accounting methods clearly reflect the income of each business. Only if you keep complete and separate books and records for each business will they be considered separate and distinct.

Most individuals and many non-inventory sole proprietors use cash accounting because they find it easier to maintain cash accounting records. However, if you need inventory to calculate your income, you usually must use accrual accounting for the items you buy and sell, except for small business taxpayers (see the definition in the later part of this chapter). For more information, see Inventory.

In accordance with cash basis, please include all income items that you actually or estimatedly received during the tax year in your total income. If you received property or services, you must include their fair market value in your income.

In the absence of restrictions, when a sum of money is credited to your account or is made available to you, you are deemed to have received it. You do not need to possess the money. If you authorize someone to act as your agent and to collect income for you, when your agent receives income, it is deemed to have been received by you.

You cannot carry over a check from one tax year to the next, or hold similar property from one tax year to the next to avoid paying income tax. You must report the income from the property in the year you receive or are provided with the property, without restriction.
If you receive a valid check during a tax year, it is assumed that you have received income during that year, even if the check cannot be cashed or deposited until the following year.

If your debt has been repaid by someone else or has been cancelled by the creditor, you may have to include part or all of the debt as income. If you receive income in this way, you are considered to have received income when the debt is cancelled or repaid. For more information, see the section on cancelled debts in chapter 5, under the heading Income from cancelled debts.

If you include an amount in your income and later in the same year repay all or part of that income, you can usually deduct the amount you repay in the year you repay it. If you repay more than $3,000, special rules apply. For more information about these special rules, see 17, Chapter 8, Repayment.

Under the cash method, you generally deduct expenses in the tax year in which you actually pay them. This includes expenses you dispute as business debts. However, you may not be able to deduct prepaid expenses, or you may need to capitalize some costs, as explained later in the uniform capitalization rules.

Under accrual accounting, you typically report income in the year you earn it and deduct expenses in the year you incur them, or capitalize them. The purpose of accrual accounting is to match income and expenses in the appropriate years.

Under the accrual method, you generally include in your total income an amount that you can reasonably estimate you will receive in the tax year in which you have the right to receive the income. If the taxpayer has applicable financial statements or the secretary may specify other financial statements, it is considered to have passed the all events test no later than in the consideration of the total income item in the applicable financial statement or other such financial statement.
Below are special rules for payment schedules for advance payments, estimated income, and changes of service.

If you include a reasonable estimate of the amount in your gross income and subsequently determine the exact amount is different, consider the difference in the tax year in which you determine the exact amount.

If you provide services at the basic rate specified in the contract, even if you agree to charge at a lower rate before completing the service and receiving the additional fee, you must calculate your income at the basic rate.

Generally, you report the advance payments as income in the year you receive them. However, if you receive advance payments, you can choose to include them in income in the following tax year. You cannot include any payments after the tax year. For more information, see the 538th and 451st notices.

In your business, when production, purchase or sale of goods is a factor in generating income, unless you are a small business taxpayer, you generally must consider inventory in the tax year beginning and ending. If you must account for inventory, you generally must use accrual accounting for the items you buy and sell. For more information, see Inventory.

You cannot deduct business expenses and interest that you owe to related parties until you have made a payment and the corresponding amount is included in the total income of the related party when using cash accounting. Due to this rule, please also determine such a relationship at the end of the tax year in which you can deduct expenses or interest. If this rule does not allow you to deduct expenses or interest, even if the relationship with the party ends before the expenses or interest can be included in the total income of the party, the rule will continue to apply. Related parties include your immediate family, including siblings (with complete or half blood relationship), your spouse, ancestors and descendants. For a list of other related parties, please refer to Section 267 of the Internal Revenue Code.

Generally, you can use the cash method, accrual method, or special accounting method of combining, provided that the combining method clearly reflects your income and expenses and you consistently use the same combining method. However, the following conditions apply. If you must consider inventory when calculating your income, you usually must use the accrual method for the items you buy and sell. (But see Inventory.) You may use the cash method for all other income and expense items. If you use the cash method when calculating your income, you must use the cash method when reporting your expenses. If you use the accrual method when reporting your expenses, you must use the accrual method when calculating your income. If you use a combining method that includes the cash method, treat that combining method as the cash method.
Generally speaking, if your business produces, purchases or sells goods, you must keep inventory and use accrual accounting for the goods you buy and sell.

If you are a small business taxpayer, you may choose not to keep inventory, but still use a certain accounting method for inventory that clearly reflects your income. If you choose not to keep inventory and your accounting method for inventory treats inventory as non-merchandise or supplies, or is consistent with your financial accounting treatment of inventory, you will not be considered to have failed to clearly reflect income. Generally, if you produce, purchase or sell goods in your business, you must keep inventory and use accrual accounting for purchases and sales of goods.

If you (a) had average annual gross income of $3 million or less for the preceding 3 tax years and (b) are not a tax-exempt organization (as defined in section 448(d)(3)), you are eligible for the small business tax. If your business did not exist for the entire 3 tax years used to calculate average gross income, you calculate average gross income based on the period of existence. If your business (or predecessor entity) had a shorter tax year in any of the 3 tax years, you calculate your business's gross income for the shorter tax year as a pro-rated amount. See IRS Publication 538 for more information.

At the beginning and end of each tax year, you must value your inventory to determine your cost of sales (Schedule C, line 42). To determine the value of your inventory, you need to use the method of identifying inventory items and the method of valuing those items. For all types of businesses, inventory valuation rules cannot be the same. The method you use to value your inventory must be consistent with the generally accepted accounting principles used by similar businesses and must clearly reflect your income. Your inventory practices must be consistent over time.

Under the uniform capitalization rules, you must capitalize the direct and part of the indirect costs of production or resale activities. Include these costs in the base used to calculate the cost of the property you produce or purchase for resale, rather than deducting them as a current deduction. You can recover the cost of the property when you use, sell, or otherwise dispose of it by deducting depreciation, amortization, or the cost of goods sold.

Unless the purpose of producing property is for use in a non-business or non-profit activity, if you are engaged in any of the following businesses, you may be required to comply with the uniform capitalization rules. Producing real property or tangible property. For this, tangible property includes films, recordings, videotapes, books, or similar property. Acquiring property for resale.

Several income or expense items are accounted for using special accounting methods. These methods include: Depreciation, discussed in 225, Chapter 7. Bad debts, discussed in 453, Topic Bad Debt Deductions. Depreciation, discussed in 225, Chapter 7. Depreciation, discussed in 946, Topic How to Depreciate Property. Installment sales, discussed in 537, Topic Installment Sales. Accounting methods for long-term contracts. See 460.

Installment sales are property sales in which the taxpayer receives at least one payment after the tax year in which the sale is made. If you provide the money for the buyer to purchase your property instead of having the buyer obtain a loan or mortgage from a third party, you may be making an installment sale. For more information about installment sales, see Publication 537.

The sale of a business is not usually the sale of only one asset. Instead, all of the business's assets are sold. Generally, when this occurs, each asset is treated as being sold separately, in order to determine how the gain or loss is to be treated. The parties to the business sale must report to the IRS how the price of the sale is allocated among the business's assets. Use Form 8594, Statement of Assets and Liabilities of a Business Acquired in a Transaction in Which There Was a Transfer of Stock of a Corporation or an Interest in a Partnership or a Limited Liability Company, to provide this information. The parties should attach a copy of Form 8594 to their respective federal income tax returns for the year of the transaction. For more information about business sales, see IRS Publication 544.

The cost or purchase price of an asset is usually the basis for calculating gain or loss on sale or disposition. However, if you acquire an asset by gift, inheritance, or other means other than purchase, you must use a basis other than its cost. For more information about basis, see Publication 551, Basis of Assets and Liabilities.

Generally, your net proceeds from the disposition of property are the total of all cash received plus the fair market value of all property or services received. Your net proceeds also include any debts assumed by the purchaser of your property and any debts attached to the property you transfer, such as real property taxes or a mortgage.

For tax purposes, you generally recognize gains or losses from the disposition of property as income or losses. Recognized gains must be included in total income. Recognized losses can be deducted from total income. However, gains or losses from certain transactions are not recognized. Refer to the section on Non-taxable transactions. Similarly, you cannot deduct losses from the disposition of property held for personal use.

You must report your gains or losses as ordinary or capital gains or losses. You must do this to calculate net capital gains or losses. Generally, if you dispose of a capital asset, you will report capital income or loss. Usually, you own and use every asset for personal or investment purposes. A property you use in your business is not a capital asset. Income or loss from the disposition of the property is ordinary income or loss. However, if you hold the property for more than 1 year, you may be able to treat the income or loss as capital gains or losses. These are called Section 1231 gains and losses. For more information about ordinary and capital gains and losses, see IRS Publication 544, chapters 2 and 3.

If you have realized a capital gain or loss, you must determine whether it is long-term or short-term. A capital gain or loss is long-term or short-term depending on how long you held the property before you disposed of it. The time you held the property before you disposed of it is called the holding period.
Please use form 6252. You may also need to use form 4797 and schedule D (form 1040).

The tax benefit applies to the startup costs of new qualified fixed benefit or fixed contribution plans (including 401(k) plans), SIMPLE plans, or SEP plans. For more information, see IRS Publication 560, Retirement Plans for Small Businesses.
The tax credit applies to wages paid to eligible employees for time off for home and family leave and for medical leave, but is subject to certain conditions. For more information, see form 8994.
The tax credit is generally available for each low-income building constructed after 1986. For more information, see Form 8586.
The tax credit provides incentives to businesses to employ individuals from target groups with high unemployment rates or other special employment needs. For more information, see form 5884.
The tax credit provides incentives to employers to continue paying wages to employees who serve in the uniformed services for more than 30 days. For more information, see form 8932.
The tax credit is available for eligible expenses for employee child care services and eligible expenses for child care resources and referral services. For more information, see form 8882.
The tax credit applies to the cost of certain health insurance provided to a number of employees. For more information, see form 8941.

This chapter explains how to calculate business income, how to report business income on your tax return, which items are not treated as income, and provides guidelines for selecting a trade. If you receive any income related to your business, that income is business income. If it is clear that you would not make an income payment if you did not conduct the business, there is an association. Even if you do not conduct your business on a full-time basis, you may have business income. Income you receive from conducting a business in addition to your regular full-time work may be business income. For example, as a second job, you may conduct a business providing ridesharing services. You should report most of your business income on Schedule C, such as income from selling your products or services. However, you should report income from selling business assets (such as land and office buildings) on other forms, not on Schedule C. For more information about selling business assets, see Chapter 3.

Revenue from business operations includes amounts received by your business that are correctly shown on your 1099-NEC form. This includes amounts reported as nonemployee compensation in box 1 of the form. For more information, see the instructions for the form on the back of the 1099-NEC form.

NIL income can be classified as self-employment income. If you receive more than $600 of NIL income from any source (including non-cash income), you should receive a 1099-NEC or 1099-MISC form from that source, which shows the amount of income you must report on your tax return.

If you conduct business, you may receive a 1099-K form that reflects the total amount of all reportable payments made to you. This may not be the amount you report as income because it may not include all of your income items and may include income items that are not included in your income items (for example, sales tax).

Your income reported on Schedule C may be eligible business income, which may allow you to take a deduction on line 13 of Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR. If you need to calculate your deduction (if any), see Form 8995-A or Form 8995.

Unless you are exempt from tax by law, you must report all income you receive from your business on your tax return, including income that the payer has not reported to you on a 1099 form. In most cases, your business income will be in the form of cash, checks, and credit card charges. Business income may also be in other forms, such as property or services. These and other types of income are explained below. If you are a U.S. citizen and you receive business income from sources outside the United States (foreign income), you must report this income on your tax return, unless you are exempt from tax by law. If you are a nonresident of the United States, you may be able to report less or none of your foreign business income. For more information, see Publication 54, Foreign Income and the Tax Law Definitions of a U.S. Citizen and a Resident Alien for Tax Purposes.

Barter is the exchange of property or services. When you receive total income, you must include in total income the fair market value of property or services you receive in exchange for other property or services. If you exchange services with another person and you and the other person have previously agreed on the value of the services, unless you can show that the value is different, the value will be treated as fair market value.

If you are a real estate trader who earns income from renting out real estate, or a hotel, motel, or other real estate owner who provides services to guests (such as a maid service), you must report rental income and expenses on Schedule C. If you are not a real estate trader or one of the above owners, you must report rental income and expenses on Schedule E. For more information, see Publication 527, Rental Income and Expenses.

If you are a self-employed tow truck lot owner, you must pay self-employment tax on the rental income you receive from providing parking spaces and facilities and tangible services to your tenants. If the services are primarily for the convenience of your tenants, rather than for maintaining occupied parking spaces, you are generally treated as providing tangible services to your tenants. If the compensation for the services constitutes a substantial part of the tenants' rent, the services are considered tangible. Examples of services that are not generally considered to be for the convenience of your tenants include supervising and maintaining the entertainment hall provided by the lot, distributing monthly e-newsletters to tenants, operating a laundry facility, and assisting tenants in buying or selling a tow truck.

If you provide services to the tenant, you must report your rental income from the hotel, hostel or apartment that the tenant uses or occupies. Generally, if the services are primarily for the tenant's convenience and are not services that are normally provided with the rental of a room that is only for the tenant's use, you will be considered to be providing services to the tenant. One type of service that is not typically for the tenant's convenience is maid service. However, providing heat and light, cleaning stairways and hallways, and collecting garbage are typically services for the tenant's convenience.
The prepayment of a lease is income to you in the year in which you receive it. It is generally the same, no matter what accounting method or period you use.

If your tenant makes payments to others under a contract to pay off your debt or liability, then include those payments in your gross income when the tenant makes the payments. A common example of this type of income is the tenant paying your property taxes on real property that is rented.

You receive income from the amount of money you receive from the tenant for restoring the rental property to its original condition. If the amount exceeds the adjustment base for repairing the rental property damaged, damaged, demolished or disassembled by the tenant, it is income.

If you are in the business of renting personal property (such as equipment, vehicles, or clothing), include the rent you receive in your gross income on Schedule C. As discussed in the discussion of real property rental income above, advance payments of rent and other payments may also be received from the rental of personal property. If you receive any of these amounts, include them in your gross income as discussed in the discussion of advance payments of rent and other payments above.
Interest earned on receipts from normal business operations is business income. If you are in the lending business, interest earned on loans is business income.

If the loan you are entitled to receive cannot be recovered within the tax year and you use accrual accounting, you generally must include the interest you accrue on the loan in your gross income until the loan becomes uncollectible. If you previously included interest that later becomes uncollectible, you may deduct bad debt. See chapter 8, Bad Debt.

If you charge little or no interest on installment sales contracts, you may have to treat part of each payment as undisclosed interest. See Revenue Ruling 537, Unstated Interest and Original Issue Discount (OID).

Generally speaking, dividends are the income of securities dealers. However, for most sole proprietors and statutory employees, dividends are non-business income. If you hold stocks as a separate investment from your business activity, dividends from stocks are non-business income. If you receive dividends from business insurance premiums you have deducted in the previous year, you must report all or part of the dividends as business income on your tax return. To determine the amount to report, see  Claiming Deductions That Were Previously Claimed , which is discussed in the following section Other Income .
The following explains the general rules and exceptions to the general rules that include debt cancellation in income.

Generally, if your debt is canceled or forgiven, you must include the canceled amount as part of your total income to pay taxes. If the debt is from your business, report the canceled amount on line 6 of Schedule C. If the debt is a nonbusiness debt, report the canceled amount on line 8c of Form 1040.
The following discuss some exceptions to the general rules of cancelled debts.

If you owe the seller money for the property you purchased, and the seller reduces the amount you owe, you usually won't receive income from the reduction in debt. Unless you are bankrupt or unable to pay, you should consider the reduced amount as a purchase price adjustment and lower your property base.
If repayment of the debt would result in a deduction, you won't get income from the cancellation of debt.

If the debt was incurred in a bankruptcy case and was not included in income, then it does not qualify for the exclusion under 2 through 5. If the debt was incurred when you were unable to repay it, and you were unable to repay it, then it does not qualify for the exclusion under 3 and 4.
In this discussion, debt includes any debt you owe or that is attached to the property you hold.

You may elect to exclude a portion of your qualified real property business debt forgiveness (up to a certain limit). If you do, you must reduce the basis of your real property by the amount of the excluded portion. This reduction is made at the beginning of the tax year in which the forgiveness occurs. However, if you dispose of the property before that, you must immediately reduce its basis before the disposition.

Eligible non-farm business debt includes the debt refinanced as described in section 3 above, but only to the extent that it is less than the refinanced debt. If you are the owner of an ignored entity (e.g., a single-member limited liability company), see the 4681 Notice, Chapter 1, Qualified non-farm business debt, to determine whether you meet the exclusion. The amount you exclude cannot exceed the lesser of the following: 1. The difference between 1. The outstanding principal of eligible non-farm business debt (immediately before the cancellation of debt); and 2. The fair market value of commercial real property used as collateral for the debt (immediately before the cancellation of debt), minus the outstanding principal of any other eligible non-farm business debt secured by the same real property (immediately before the cancellation of debt). 2. The total adjusted basis of real property held by you immediately before the cancellation of debt. These adjusted bases are determined after any adjustments to the bases of real property acquired in exchange for the debt cancellation or cancellation of eligible farm debt. Do not consider real property acquired in exchange for the debt cancellation.
The following discussion explains how to handle other types of business income that you may receive.

In the following situations, you must deduct the amount of depreciation you claimed. This means that you must include in your income the amount of depreciation you claimed in a prior year, or all of it, if you claimed it all.

If, in the tax year after you place the property in use, your use of the property (explained in Section 8 Depreciation) falls to 50% or less, you may have to reverse part of the depreciation deduction. You can include part of the depreciation you claimed in a prior year on your Schedule C. Use Form 4797, Part IV, to figure the amount to include. For more information, see What are the use requirements? in Publication 946, pages 5-1 through 5-10. That publication explains how to determine whether your use of the property is more than 50%.

If you take a deduction for depreciation under section 179 (explained in depreciation under chapter 8), and the asset is disposed of before the end of its recovery period or its use rate falls to 50% or less, you must reclaim part of the deduction. You can include the amount of the deduction you took in your Schedule C income. Use Form 4797, Part IV, to figure the amount to include on your Schedule C. See Publication 946, chapter 2, to find out when you can reclaim the deduction.

If you receive income from the sale or exchange of depreciable property, you may have to treat all or part of the depreciation as ordinary income. Calculate the income from depreciation deductions in Part III of Form 4797. For more information, see IRS Publication 544, Chapter 4.

Please report on Schedule C any sales or transactions of property held as trading stock or primarily for sale to customers. You generally report when you receive them the face amount (less any unstated interest) or issue price (for OID debt instruments) shown on them.

If you reduce or terminate your business activity, report on Schedule C any payments you receive from insurance or other sources because of lost business income. Even if you receive the payment while your business is inactive, report the payment on Schedule C.

You must include in your gross income any damages you received during the tax year for any of the following that are related to your business. Patent infringement. Breach of contract or loyalty. Antitrust damages.

You may be entitled to deduct from your income, if it compensates for your actual economic loss. Your deduction is the lesser of the amount of the loss you received or accrued during the tax year and the amount you paid or incurred during the tax year to recover the loss. Your loss from the unclaimed loss.

If you receive any refunds, include them in your income on Schedule C. However, if you have already treated the refunds as a reduction in your related expenses, capital expenditures, or cost of goods sold, do not include them.

If you recover bad debts or any other items that you have deducted in a prior year, include the amount recovered in your gross income on Schedule C. However, if all or part of the amount deducted in an earlier year did not reduce your tax, you may not include that part of the amount recovered. If you do not include part of the amount recovered in your gross income, you must attach a statement to your return showing how you calculated the amount not included.
In some circumstances, the property or money you receive is not income.
Any increase in the value of your property before you realize a gain from its sale or other taxable disposition is not income.

If a tenant builds a structure or improves your property, the increased value of the property from the improvement is not your income. However, if the facts show that the improvement is a way of paying you rent, the increased value will be income.
