You must collect and remit to the state or local government the sales tax that the seller levies on the buyer. This is not income.

The sale of goods to others on your behalf is not a sale. Even after the consignee receives the goods, ownership of the goods remains with you (the consignor). Therefore, if you transport goods on a consignment basis, you will not incur any profit or loss before the consignee sells the goods. Goods transported on a consignment basis are included in your inventory until they are sold. Please do not include goods received on a consignment basis in your inventory. When you sell goods consigned to you or receive goods from a consignee, include any profits or commissions in your income, but this depends on the accounting method you use.

Certain medical assistance exemption payments reported to you on Form 1099-MISC or Form 1099-NEC may not be taxable. For more information on how to report these payments, see the instructions for Schedule C (Form 1040).

If you entered into a lease after August 5, 1997, and you received construction allowances from your landlord in either of the following circumstances, you do not include the construction allowances in your income. Under a short-term retail space lease. To construct or improve a qualified long-term real property for your business use.

Short-term leases are retail space leases (or other occupancy or use agreements) of 15 years or less. The following rules apply to determine whether a lease is 15 years or less. In determining whether a lease is 15 years or less, consider any continuation options. However, do not consider any continuation options that are determined at continuation by fair market value. If two or more consecutive leases are part of the same or substantially similar retail space transaction (or series of related transactions), the leases are considered to be one lease.

Whether or not the income is reported on your tax return, you must report the income. If you meet all of the following conditions, you are a direct seller. 1. You are engaged in the following type of transaction or business. 1. Selling or soliciting sales of consumer products at your home or at another place other than a regular retail store. 2. Delivering or distributing newspapers or shopping news (including any services related to such transactions or businesses). 2. You pay most of the money (whether in cash or otherwise) for the services you provide directly related to sales or other results (including providing services) other than the number of hours worked. 3. You provide services based on a written contract with the person who receives the services, and the contract states that you are not an employee for federal tax purposes.

If you are an authorized real estate broker or direct seller and you meet both of the following conditions, you must report your income on Schedule C. As a real estate broker or direct seller, all of your service fees are generally directly related to your sales or other output, rather than to the number of hours you work. You provide services under a written contract that states that you are not an employee for federal tax purposes.

If you are a futures commission merchant, you must report income and losses from transactions or sales of Section 1256 contracts (regulated futures contracts, foreign currency contracts, non-equity options, futures on securities, and futures on securities options) or property related to these contracts (such as stocks used to hedge options) on Schedule C. For more information, see Section 1256 and Section 1402(i).

If you are engaged in the business of buying and selling securities or commodities for your own account, you are a securities or commodities trader. As a securities or commodities (including if you made an election under section 475(f) to treat your securities or commodities trading as trading in a business) trader, you do not report your gains or losses from the disposition of securities or commodities on Schedule C. For more information about securities or commodities traders, see Revenue Ruling 55-603, Income from Trading in Securities and Commodities, and Topic 429 - Securities Traders.

If you meet all of the following conditions, you are not required to report the severance fees you receive from the insurance company as income on Schedule C. You receive payment after the end of the agreement you have with the company. You do not provide services to the company after the end of your agreement and before the end of the year in which you receive payment. You enter into an agreement that you will not compete with the company for at least one year after the end of your agreement. The amount of the payment is primarily based on the extent to which you sell or credit to your account policies during your final year of service with the company, or the extent to which these policies remain in force during a period after your service agreement ends, or both. The amount of the payment is not based on the length of service or the extent of any overall income you receive from providing services to the company (whether or not the payment is based on the length of service).

Insurance companies must report on Form C the income they pay to self-employed insurance agents before retirement based on the commission percentage. Likewise, the commission on renewal or deferred commission on pre-retirement sales is usually reported on Form C. However, the commission on renewal paid to the agent's heirs is not reported on Form C.

Public employees generally do not need to report income from public service on Schedule C. This rule applies to elected tax collectors who receive payments from state funds based on a fixed percentage of collected taxes. Public employees include any elected or appointed position in the United States or its territories, the District of Columbia, a state or a secondary political subdivision or higher. If a public employee is paid on a fee basis and their service meets the conditions for social security under a federal or state agreement, but is not yet covered by such insurance, then they must report fees from the public on Schedule C.

The methods used to account for income for income tax purposes may sometimes differ from the methods used for accounting purposes. This section discusses some of the more common differences that may affect business transactions. Calculate business income (see Chapter 2) for the tax year and your usual accounting method. If the sale of products is a factor in generating your business income, you generally must use inventory to clearly reflect your income. Real estate dealers may not use inventory. For more information about inventory, see Chapter 2.
You must pay tax on all income you earn. You cannot avoid tax by paying income to a third party.

You must use the selected method to apply all purchase discount each year. If you use another method, your account balance at the end of the tax year is your gross income. Under this method, you cannot reduce your cost of goods sold by the amount of the cash discount you receive. When you estimate the value of inventory at the end of the tax year, you cannot subtract the average or estimated discount received on the goods from the invoice price of the goods you have on hand at the end of the tax year.

If the purchaser of your property places part or all of the purchase price in a trust, do not include any part of the purchase price in your gross income until you actually or constructively receive the purchase price. However, you will have taxable income even if you do not receive the purchase price in the following year after you have performed the contract and the trust agreement.

If you receive compensation for an accident or theft, you must reduce the loss by the amount of the compensation when you calculate the deduction. You cannot deduct the portion of the loss that is compensated. For information about accidents or thefts, see publication 547.

If you manufacture or buy goods to sell, you can deduct the cost of goods sold from your gross income on Schedule C. However, to determine these costs, you must estimate the value of your inventory at the beginning and end of each tax year. If you are a manufacturer, wholesaler, or carry on any business of producing, buying, or selling goods to make a profit, this chapter applies to you. This chapter does not apply to businesses that provide personal services, such as doctors, lawyers, carpenters, or painters. However, if you provide personal services and also sell or charge for materials and supplies that are used in your business, or that are used in the performance of your personal services, this chapter applies to you. There are some exceptions for small business taxpayers. These exceptions may change the way you calculate your business's cost of goods sold. See chapter 2 for more information.

If you donate inventory (i.e., property you sell in your business), you can claim a donation deduction equal to the smaller of the fair market value of the inventory on the date of donation or the inventory base in the year of donation. The base of donated inventory is the inventory you would have included in your beginning inventory at the beginning of the year, or in an earlier year, due to inventory costs. You must subtract your donation deduction from your beginning inventory. This is not part of your cost of goods sold. If the cost of donated inventory is not included in your beginning inventory, the base is zero, so you cannot claim a charitable donation deduction. Handle inventory costs according to your usual accounting method. For example, include the purchase price of inventory purchased and donated during the year in your cost of goods sold for that year.

The difference between the stated price of the goods and the actual price you pay for those goods is called a trade discount. When calculating the purchase cost, you must use the price you pay (not the stated price). Do not separately show the discount amount as a separate item in the total income. Automobile dealers must record the cost of inventory automobiles and subtract any manufacturer's trade discount.

Cash discount is the amount your supplier allows you to deduct from your purchase invoices to pay on time. There are two methods of recording cash discount. You can record the cash discount to a separate discount account on the debit side, or you can deduct the total amount of purchases in the year. Regardless of which method you use, you must consistently use it. If you want to change the method of recording inventory cost, you must submit form 3115. For more information, see Section 2 Changing Accounting Methods. If you record the cash discount to a separate account on the debit side, at the end of the tax year, you must include the balance of that account in your gross income. If you use this method, you cannot use the cash discount to lower your cost of goods sold.

If you take goods for personal or household use, you must deduct the cost of those goods from the total amount you paid for the goods you sold. Record the cost of the goods you take for personal or household use on the debit side of the purchase or sales account. You must also deduct that amount from your drawing account. The drawing account is a separate account you must keep to record the income you use to pay personal and household expenses. As mentioned above, you also use the drawing account to record goods you take for personal or household use. That account is also called a drawing account or personal account.

Direct labor costs are the wages you pay to employees who work full-time on the production of goods. These costs also include part of the wages you pay to part-time employees who work directly on the production of goods (if you can determine this part of the wages).

Indirect labor costs are the wages you pay to employees who perform general factory functions that are not directly or immediately related to the production of saleable products, but are an essential part of the production process.
As part of the product, containers and packaging are part of the cost of goods sold. If containers and packaging are not part of the product, then these costs are transportation or selling expenses.
The freight costs, shipping costs, and delivery costs of raw materials, supplies, and goods that you purchase for sale are all part of your selling expenses.

Management expenses include rent, heat, lighting, electricity, insurance, depreciation, taxes, maintenance, labor, and supervision. Management expenses incurred as a direct necessity of manufacturing operations are included in your cost of goods sold.

The 40th row minus the value of your year-end inventory (in appropriate cases, including raw materials and supplies cost, direct labor cost and management fee portion). Year-end inventory is also called year-end or final inventory. Your final inventory usually becomes the beginning inventory of the next tax year.

First calculate net income, then calculate gross profit. Please subtract any refunds and allowances (Line 2) from total income (Line 1) to calculate net income (Line 3) on Schedule C. Refunds and allowances include cash refunds, discounts, and other allowances given to customers during the year. Then subtract net income (Line 3) from cost of goods sold (Line 4). The result is your gross profit.

If your sales activities are not a material part of your business income, you do not need to calculate your cost of sales. Your gross income and your net income are the same (total income minus any refunds, allowances, or other allowances). Most businesses and professions that sell services (rather than products) can calculate their gross income directly from net income in this way.

At the end of each business day, ensure that your records match the actual cash and deductions for that day. You may find that using a cash register helps you keep track of income. You should also use an appropriate invoicing system and open a separate bank account for your business.

Please verify, to ensure that your records show the correct amount of sales tax collected. If you are a seller of goods or services, you must include the amount you collect in your total income. If you must collect state and local sales tax from the buyer and remit it to the state or local government, you generally do not need to include these amounts in your income.

If you use any inventory item for personal use (self-use, providing to family members, or as a personal gift, etc.), make sure to remove these items from your cost of goods sold. For details on how to adjust cost of goods sold, see Chapter 6, Goods Sold from Inventory.

Please verify to ensure you have adequate inventory count procedures. These procedures should ensure that all items are included in inventory and that appropriate pricing techniques are used. Please use the inventory sheets and tally sheets as the only evidence of inventory. Inventory sheets may be obtained at office supply stores. These sheets have columns for recording description, quantity, unit price, and the value of each inventory item. Each page has blank space to record the person who performed the count, the person who priced the item, the person who performed the extension, and the person who verified the calculation. These sheets will help you confirm that the total inventory is accurate. These sheets will also provide permanent records to attest to their validity. Inventory is discussed in Chapter 2.

If you are in the retail or wholesale business, you can check the accuracy of your gross margin. First, divide your net income by your gross margin. The resulting percentage can measure the average price difference between your cost of goods sold and your selling price. Then, compare that percentage to your mark-up policy. If the two percentages are close or the same, then your gross margin is accurate. If the two percentages are significantly different, then it may indicate that you have not accurately calculated your sales, purchases, inventory, or other cost items. You should determine the cause of the discrepancy.

You run a retail business. Typically, you would add a markup to your products, so that you could earn 331/3% of the sales revenue. Your profit and loss statement shows a net income (total revenue minus returns and allowances) of $300,000. Your cost of goods sold is $200,000. Thus, you earn a $100,000 markup (300,000 - 200,000). To verify the accuracy of your performance for the year, you divide net income ($300,000) by markup ($100,000). The result of 331/3% proves that your 331/3% markup percentage is correct.

If your business receives income from sources other than normal business operations, enter the income on line 6 of Schedule C and add it to gross income. This is total business income. Examples include income from interest-bearing checking accounts, income from the sale of scrap, income from certain fuel tax credits and refunds, and income from bad debts recovered.

SEP, SIMPLE, and eligible plans offer a tax-advantaged way for you and your employees to save for retirement. You can deduct your contributions to the plan on line 19 of Schedule C. If you are self-employed, you can deduct your contributions on line 16 of Form 1040. If your contributions do not cover the trustee's fees, you can deduct those fees. Income from contributions to a plan generally is not taxed until distributions are made to you or your employees. If you start a new eligible fixed contribution or fixed benefit plan (including a 401(k) plan), you may be able to claim a tax benefit. For more information about this tax benefit and the tax benefit for automatic enrollment and military spouse participation, see Form 8881 and its separate instructions. Under certain plans, your employees may allow you to make a small amount of pre-tax salary contributions to the plan. These amounts (and income earned on them) are generally not taxed until distributions are made to your employees. For more information about small business retirement plans, see Publication 560. Publication 590-A, Individual Retirement Accounts (IRAs), discusses other ways to save for retirement in a tax-advantaged way.

You cannot claim a deduction for rental income that is not reasonable. Generally, if you and the landlord are related, there will be a question of reasonableness. If you pay the same amount of rent to a related person as you would to a stranger who uses the same property, it is reasonable. Rent is not unreasonable simply because it is calculated as a percentage of your total income. Related persons include your immediate family, including siblings (with complete or half blood relationship), your spouse, your ancestors and your descendants. For a list of other related persons, see Internal Revenue Code § 267.

You can deduct your business's direct state taxes from your gross income (not net income) on Schedule C. If you list each deduction separately, you can deduct other state and local income taxes on Schedule A (1040 form). Do not deduct federal income taxes.

You may deduct as taxes the Social Security, Medicare, and FUTA taxes that you pay as an employer with your own funds. Employment taxes are discussed in Chapter 1. You may also deduct as taxes payments you make as an employer to the state unemployment compensation fund or to the state disability benefits fund. Treat these payments as taxes.

Please treat any sales tax you pay on a service or on the purchase or use of property as part of the cost of the service or property. If the service, cost, or property is used for a business expense that is deductible, you can deduct the tax as part of the service or cost. If the property is a commodity purchased for resale, the sales tax is part of the cost of the commodity. If the property is depreciated, add the sales tax to the depreciated base. For information about property base, see Publication 551. Do not deduct sales tax collected from the purchaser. You must collect and formally pay this sales tax to the state or local government. Do not include this tax in your gross income or total sales.

You can usually deduct the amount of travel and meal expenses that you have reported as business expenses. The amount you can deduct and the way you can deduct the expenses depend on whether you are reporting expenses under a cash-or-accrual plan or a noncash-or-accrual plan. For more information, see Publication 15. Publication 15 explains the cash-or-accrual plan and the noncash-or-accrual plan, and tells you whether you must report the expenses on your employee's Form W-2.
You may deduct the cost of using these vehicles and other types of transportation between the airport or station and your hotel, or between your hotel and your home office.
You may deduct the cost of shipping luggage and samples or display materials between your normal and temporary work locations.

To meet the requirements of the common test, you must use your home's specific area for business purposes. If you only use the area occasionally or incidentally, even if you do not use the area for any other purpose, you do not meet the test requirements.

You may also be able to deduct the following expenses. Advertising. Bank fees. Donations to commercial organizations. Educational expenses. Depreciation related expenses. Interview expense allowance. Permit and regulatory fees. Moving machinery. Re-employment services. Any fines and penalties you pay for late or non-performance of a contract. Repairs and maintenance of real property or tangible personal property. Repayment of income. Supplies and materials. Utilities.

You cannot generally deduct the following as business expenses. Bribes and kickbacks. Donations to charity. Relocation or loss expenses. Business, social, athletic, lunch, exercise, air, and hotel club dues. Entertainment expenses. Improvements to real property or tangible personal property. Improvements are amounts paid for engineering work to improve property, restore property, or make property suitable for a new or other use. Lobbying expenses. Fines and penalties you pay to a government agency or department for a violation of the law. Personal, living, and home expenses. Political contributions. Settlement payments or payments related to sexual harassment or sexual assault (if the settlement payments or payments are subject to a nondisclosure agreement). You also cannot deduct legal fees related to the settlement payments or payments.

If someone owes you money and you can't get it back, you have bad debts. There are two kinds of bad debts - business bad debts and non-business bad debts. Business bad debts are usually debts from running your business or your business operations. As an expense, you may be able to deduct business bad debts on your tax return.

If your primary motivation for assuming a debt is business reasons, then the debt is related to your business. Business bad debts are primarily due to sales on credit to customers. Business bad debts may also be due to loans to suppliers, customers, employees, or distributors. Goods and services for which customers have not paid are shown in your books as accounts receivable or notes receivable. If you are unable to collect any part of these accounts receivable or notes receivable, the uncollectible part is business bad debts. You can only deduct business bad debts when the amount you owe is included in your gross income for the year you file the deduction or for the preceding year.

If you claim a bad debt deduction on your income tax return and later recover (recoup) all or part of it, you may have to include all or part of the amount recovered in your total income. You include only the amount you actually claimed as a deduction. However, you can exclude the amount of the deduction that did not reduce your tax. Report the amount recovered as 'Other income' on the appropriate business form or schedule. For more information, see 525. Recoupment.

All other bad debts are nonbusiness bad debts, and may be deducted as short-term capital losses on Form 8949 and Schedule D (Form 1040). For more information on nonbusiness bad debts, see section 166 and its instructions.

If you use accrual accounting, you usually report income when you earn it. If you have already included uncollectible amounts in your income, you can deduct bad debts corresponding to the uncollectible amounts you receive.

If you use cash accounting, you typically report income when you receive payment. If you do not include in your income amounts owed to you by others that you have not received and cannot collect, you cannot take a bad debt deduction for these.

If you sell a business but retain its accounts receivable, these debts are business debts because they are generated by your trade or business. If these accounts receivable subsequently become worthless, the loss is still business bad debt.

The losses incurred by acquiring the debts of a deceased person from the estate of the deceased are determined in the same way as the debts acquired by the acquiring company. If the debts become worthless due to the deceased's trade or business, the executor of the deceased's estate will treat any losses caused by the debts as business bad debts. Otherwise, these debts will be treated as non-business bad debts in the deceased's estate.
If you liquidate your business and some of your receivables become worthless, they will be considered business bad debts.
If you lend money to customers, suppliers, employees, or distributors for business purposes and are unable to collect the loan, you have business bad debts.

If a political party (or other organization that accepts donations or spends money to influence elections) owes you money and the debt becomes worthless, you can only claim a bad debt deduction if you meet all of the following requirements. 1. You use the accrual method of accounting. 2. The debt is due to sales of goods or services in the normal course of your trade or business. 3. More than 30% of the sales of receivables in the year of accrual are from sales to the party. 4. You have made a substantial and continuing effort to collect the debt.
If, based on the facts and circumstances, the loan you provided to the company is actually an investment in capital, you cannot claim bad debt deduction.

If your partnership breaks up and one of your former partners is unable to pay his share of the partnership debts, you may have to pay more than your share of the partnership debts. If you pay any part of the debt of the insolvent partner, you can claim a bad debt deduction for the amount you pay that is the insolvent partner's share.

If the debt you have guaranteed subsequently becomes worthless and meets all of the following requirements, then the debt qualifies as a business bad debt. You made the guarantee in the course of trade or business. You have a legal obligation to repay the debt. You made the guarantee before the debt became worthless. If you reasonably expected to be relieved of the debt in the absence of full repayment by the borrower, then you meet this requirement. You received reasonable compensation for making the guarantee. If you made the guarantee in accordance with normal business practice or for good business purposes, then you meet this requirement.
If you paid a secured loan, you can deduct it in the year you paid it, unless you have a right to the loan.

When you pay off the loan you are guaranteed to pay, you may be entitled to take over the loan. So you become the creditor of this debt. If you own this debt or other rights to require the borrower to pay, you cannot claim bad debt deduction until these rights are partially or completely worthless.
If you have two or more debtors who owe you money, you cannot collect from one of them, then you cannot deduct the corresponding amount as bad debt.
If the sale price of the property that is pledged or secured is less than the debt, then the unpaid, unrecoverable debt amount is a bad debt.

When the amount owed is not repayable, the debt becomes worthless. This may occur on the due date of the debt or before. To prove that the debt is worthless, you only need to prove that you have taken reasonable steps to collect the debt, but cannot recover it.

If you receive property in part payment of a debt, reduce the debt by the FMV of the property. The FMV will become the property's basis. If the remaining debt becomes worthless, you can deduct it as a bad debt. If you later sell the property for more than its basis, any gain will be attributed to the property's appreciation. This is not a bad debt recovery. For information about the sale of property, see Pub 544.

You can deduct a portion of bad debts that are uncollectible in the tax year in which they are incurred. Your deduction is limited to the amount you write off in your books in that year. You do not have to write off and deduct a portion of worthless debts each year. You can defer the write-off to a later year. However, after the debt becomes completely worthless, you cannot deduct any part of the debt. There are two rules to consider when it comes to writing off debts: Significant modifications. For debts that have been significantly modified and the holder has confirmed income, there is an exception to the write-off rules. For more information, see Regulation 1.166-3(a)(3). Disallowed deductions. Generally, you can only deduct a portion of the bad debt deduction in the year in which you write it off in your books. If the IRS does not allow you to deduct a portion of the debt in an audit and the debt becomes completely worthless in a later tax year, you can deduct the amount you wrote off in that year plus the amount that was not allowed to be written off in previous years. Unless you make a journal entry to reverse the write-off, the write-off from previous years will satisfy the write-off requirement for a later year.

If the debt becomes worthless in the current tax year, you can deduct the full amount of the debt minus any amount you previously deducted in a prior tax year when the debt was only partly worthless. You don't have to make a book entry to deduct the bad debt. However, you may want to make a book entry. If you don't, and the IRS later determines that the debt was only partly worthless, you won't be able to deduct the debt in the tax year in which it became totally worthless, because the deduction for a partly worthless bad debt is limited to the amount of the actual writeoff.

Local business travel expenses do not include expenses incurred when you travel away from home at night. These expenses may be claimed as business expenses and are discussed in the section on travel and subsistence below. However, if you use your own car when you travel away from home overnight, you must calculate your car expenses using the rules in this section. Generally, wherever your home is located, your tax residence is the city or general area in which you carry on business or work.

In addition to the standard mileage rate, you can deduct any parking fees and tolls that are related to your business. (Parking fees paid to park at your workplace are not deductible commuting expenses.)

If property meets all the following requirements, then you can depreciate the property. It must be property that you own. It must be used in your business or can generate income. Since inventory is not held because it is used in your business, you can never depreciate inventory (explained in Chapter 2). Its useful life must be longer than the year it is placed in service. Its useful life must be determinable, meaning it must be subject to wear, decay, exhaustion, obsolescence, or natural deterioration. Since land will not wear, become obsolete, or be exhausted, you can never depreciate the cost of land. It cannot be an excluded property. This includes property that is used and disposed of in the same year.

You may choose to treat some of the repairs or replacements of your business or transactions as improvements that may be depreciated. If you treat these amounts as capital expenditures in your books and records that are regularly used to calculate income and expenses, you may choose to do so.

You are typically allowed to deduct the premiums you pay for the following types of insurance related to your business. 1. Fire, theft, flood, or similar insurance. 2. Credit insurance that covers bad debts of your business. 3. Group health and medical insurance for your employees, including long-term care insurance. 4. Liability insurance. 5. Professional liability insurance that covers negligence, resulting in injury or damage to patients or customers. 6. Workers' compensation insurance as required by state law, but only to the extent that it covers any claims for bodily injury or work-related disease of your employees, whether or not there is fault. 7. If state unemployment insurance fund contributions are treated as a tax under state law, they may be deducted as a tax. 8. Disability insurance that covers business expenses incurred during a period of disability due to injury or illness. 9. Automobile and other vehicle insurance that covers liability, damage, and other losses of vehicles used by your business. If part of the vehicle is used for personal purposes, only deduct the portion of the premium that relates to its business use. If you use the standard mileage rate to calculate your auto expenses, you cannot deduct any auto insurance premiums. 10. Life insurance that provides benefits to your employees (if you do not directly or indirectly benefit from the life insurance contract). 11. Business interruption insurance that compensates for lost profits if your business is closed due to fire or other causes.

You cannot deduct the premiums for the following types of insurance. 1. Reserve funds for self-insurance. You cannot deduct the amount recorded as a reserve for self-insurance. Even if you cannot purchase business insurance for some business risks, this also applies. However, you can deduct the actual loss. For more information, see 547. 2. Income reduction. You cannot deduct the premiums for insurance that pays for income lost due to illness or disability. However, see item 8 above. 3. Certain life insurance and annuities. 1. As to policies issued before June 9, 1997, if you are the direct or indirect beneficiary of life insurance that insures you, your employees, or any other person in whom you have a financial interest in your business, you cannot deduct the premiums for such policies. If the policyholder is required to repay the loan you have made with the proceeds of the policy, you are among the potential beneficiaries of the policy. If a person is the owner or part owner of your business and makes a loan to your business, that person has a financial interest in your business. 2. As to policies issued after June 8, 1997, if you are the direct or indirect beneficiary, you generally cannot deduct the premiums for life insurance, savings-type policies, or annuity-type policies. No matter who the insured is, the premiums cannot be deducted. 4. Insurance for obtaining a loan. If you purchase life insurance for yourself or for another person in whom you have a financial interest in your business to obtain a business loan or to provide security for a business loan, you cannot deduct the premiums as business expenses. You also cannot deduct the premiums as business loan interest or financing loan expenses. If you or the person dies and the proceeds of the policy are used to pay off the debt, these proceeds will not be treated as income and will not be taxed.
You may be able to deduct the amount you paid for medical and dental insurance and eligible long-term care insurance purchased for you and your family.

If you have or are considering a health insurance plan offered by your employer and you are applying for a premium tax credit, please refer to Form 8962 and its separate instructions and use Publication 974.

Several taxpayers must limit their business interest expense deduction. See the instructions for Form 8990 to determine whether you must limit your business interest expense deduction, who must file Form 8990, and how some businesses can elect to not comply with the business interest expense limitation. You cannot deduct interest you pay on a loan that is partly for business use and partly for personal use. If the loan is partly for business use and partly for personal use, you must separate the business and personal portions of the interest.

Other considerations are as follows. How to allocate interest between personal use and business use. Business interest limitations. When to deduct interest. Rules for loans at less than market rate (usually no interest or interest at less than the applicable federal rate).

If the fees of lawyers and professionals (such as the fees charged by accountants) are ordinary and necessary expenses directly related to the operation of your business, you can deduct these fees on Schedule C. However, you generally cannot deduct fees paid for acquiring business assets. Add these fees to the base of the property. If the fees include personal work (such as making a will), you can only claim the portion related to your business on the business deduction.

In tax matters, a non-U.S. citizen is an individual who is not a U.S. citizen. Non-U.S. citizens are divided into non-tax-law residents and tax-law residents. This publication will help you determine your status and provide you with the information you need to file a U.S. income tax return. Tax-law residents generally are taxed on their worldwide income, as are U.S. citizens. Non-tax-law residents are taxed only on their income from sources within the United States and on certain income related to trade or business in the United States.

Residents (and certain tax residents) of countries with which the United States has an income tax treaty may be eligible for certain benefits. Most treaties require that non-tax residents be residents of the treaty country in order to qualify for benefits in the year in which they are claimed. However, for certain students, interns, teachers, or researchers, some treaties require only that the non-tax resident be a resident of the treaty country at the time of arrival in the United States.

You can access the Treaty Tables at IRS.gov/TreatyTables (English). You can access the text of recently signed U.S. income tax treaties, protocols, and Tax Information Exchange Agreements (TIEA), as well as the accompanying Treasury Technical Description (which becomes publicly available), and the U.S. Income Tax Treaty Model, at Home.Treasury.gov/Policy-Issues/Tax-Policy/International-Tax (English). Note that the treaty and TIEA documents are posted on this website after they are signed, approved, and in force. The full text of personal income tax treaties can also be found at IRS.gov/Businesses/International-Businesses/United-States-Income-Tax-Treaties-A-to-Z (English). For more information about these tax treaties, visit IRS.gov/Individuals/International-Taxpayers/Tax-Treaties (English). You can usually arrange to have taxes withheld on income that is eligible for treaty benefits reduced or eliminated. See Chapter 8, Income eligible for treaty benefits (English).

Non-tax law residents' agreement income is total income that is limited by the tax treaty. Agreement income includes dividends from U.S. sources, etc., and is taxed at a tax treaty rate of no more than 15%. Non-agreement income is total income that is not limited by the tax treaty for non-tax law residents. To determine the tax on income that is taxed at the lower tax treaty rate, calculate the tax on agreement income under the lower tax rate applicable to the income under the agreement. To determine the tax on non-agreement income, calculate the tax at a flat rate of 30% or a progressive rate, depending on whether the income is effectively linked to your U.S. trade or business. Your tax liability is the total of the tax on agreement income and the tax on non-agreement income, but not more than the tax liability calculated before the tax treaty goes into effect.

Below is a brief description of the exemptions available for personal service income, remittances, scholarships, fellowships, and capital gains under tax treaties. The conditions for claiming exemptions vary from treaty to treaty. For more information on the conditions under specific tax treaties, download the text of most U.S. tax treaties at IRS.gov/Businesses/International-Businesses/United-States-Income-Tax-Treaties-A-to-Z (English). That website also provides technical explanations for many of the treaties. Also, see Publication 901 (English). Tax treaty exemptions also cover dividends, interest, rents, royalties, pensions, and annuities. These types of income may be exempt from U.S. taxes or taxed at a lower rate. For more information, see Publication 901 (English) or the applicable tax treaty.

Under most tax treaties, residents of treaty countries who are not tax residents by definition, and dual-status residents who temporarily provide services in the United States and are beneficial to the treaty country (see Chapter 1), may qualify for a partial or total exemption from United States tax on their personal income, if they meet the applicable treaty provisions.

Some tax treaties contain a 'Independent Personal Services' provision, which allows residents of the treaty country to be exempt from U.S. tax on income earned as an independent contractor or self-employed person, provided that they spend less than a certain number of days in the U.S. and do not have a permanent base of operations in the U.S.

According to many tax treaties, non-resident foreign teachers or professors who are visiting the United States primarily for teaching at a university or other approved educational institution are exempt from paying United States income tax on teaching income for the first two or three years after arrival in the United States. Many treaties provide exemptions for participation in research. In general, the purpose of the teacher or professor in the United States is teaching, lecturing, advising, or conducting research. The person must spend most of his or her time on these duties. The normal duties of a teacher or professor include not only formal classroom work (involving regular arrangements of lectures, demonstrations, or other student-participating activities), but also informal presentation of methods in seminars or other informal groups, and in laboratory sessions.

All agreements contain provisions for the exemption of income earned by certain foreign government employees. However, there are differences among the agreements as to who is eligible for this benefit. Under many agreements, a foreign national who is a resident of the United States is not eligible. Under most agreements, a non-national or non-citizen of the foreign government is not eligible. Foreign government employees should carefully read the relevant agreement to determine whether they are eligible for the benefit. Chapter 10 of this publication (in English) also contains information applicable to foreign government employees.

Once you become a tax resident, you usually cannot qualify for tax treaty exemption for this income. However, if you enter the United States as a non-tax resident but are now a tax resident for U.S. tax purposes, in the following circumstances the treaty exemption will continue to apply: the treaty retention provision (introduced above) provides an exception, and you still meet the treaty exemption requirements (including any time limits for applying the treaty exemption (in English), introduced below). Even if you are a non-tax resident who chooses to file a joint return (in English), as described in Chapter 1. If you meet the treaty retention provision's exception, you can avoid income tax withholding by requesting a W-9 form from the payor and a statement of the W-9 form instructions.

You do not need to file Form 8833 for any of the following circumstances. 1. You request a reduced withholding tax rate on interest, dividends, rents, royalties, or other FDAP income (usually subject to a 30% tax rate). 2. You request a reduced or modified tax rate on non-independent personal service income, pensions, annuities, social security, or other public pensions, or on artist, athlete, student, intern, or teacher income, including scholarships and grants. 3. You request a reduced or modified tax rate on income under an international social security agreement or a diplomatic or consular agreement. 4. You are a partner in a partnership or a beneficiary of a trust, and the partnership or trust reports required information on its tax return. 5. The total amount of payments or income items that need to be disclosed is less than $10,000. 6. You are claiming a benefit under the following circumstances: 1. reported on Form 1042-S to you; and 2. received by you: 1. as a related person to a reporting company as defined in Section 6038A, and the reporting company files Form 5472, or 2. as a beneficiary, that is, a direct account holder with a U.S. financial institution or a qualified intermediary, or the U.S. financial institution, qualified intermediary, or foreign partnership or trust as a direct partner, beneficiary, or withholding tax partner of the foreign partnership or trust. The exceptions in paragraph (6) above do not apply to any amounts disclosed on a Form 8833 that are required to be reported on a Form 1042-S as part of a special reporting requirement.

Employees of international organizations may be exempt from paying taxes on their salaries under the provisions of the international agreement(s) under which the international organization was created (if any) or by satisfying the requirements of the United States tax code. An 'international organization' is an organization designated by the President of the United States by executive order as eligible for the privileges, exemptions, and immunities of the International Organizations Immunities Act. The exemptions discussed in this chapter apply only to compensation for official services for a foreign government or international organization. Other U.S. source income of individuals who qualify for this exemption may be subject to full U.S. taxation or may qualify for favorable treatment under the provisions of applicable tax treaties. The treatment of such income (interest, dividends, etc.) is discussed in the preceding section of this publication.

You should first consult the provisions of the Vienna Convention or the bilateral consular conventions (if any) on the exemption of income, to determine whether your salary qualifies for exemption from US income tax under these provisions. Generally, if you are a US citizen or a resident for tax purposes, you are not eligible for exemption from US income tax under the Vienna Convention or the bilateral consular conventions. For more information on the Vienna Convention and the bilateral consular conventions, please send an email to the Office of Foreign Missions of the Department of State: OFMAssistants@state.gov (English).

If you do not qualify for tax exemption under the Vienna Convention or a bilateral consular convention, but are from a country that has a tax treaty with the United States, you should consult the tax treaty to determine whether there is a provision for exempting your salary from United States income tax. If you are a United States citizen or a resident for tax purposes under the tax laws, your salary is generally not exempt from United States income tax. For more information, see Foreign Government Payments of Salaries and Annuities in Publication 901 (pdf).

However, please refer to the Foreign National (Legally Permanent Resident) in the text below for the special rules that may affect your eligibility for this exemption. To qualify for the exemption, you must be able to prove that you meet the requirements of the US tax code.

The best way to establish that you are eligible for similar service and equivalent tax-free treatment without having to meet the requirements of US tax law is to obtain a certificate from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA). For information on whether you have a certificate, its current validity, and its applicability to you, please send an email to the MOFA office at OFMAssistants@state.gov (English). If you do not have a valid certificate, you must establish through other written evidence that the services you provide are of a similar nature to those provided by US government employees abroad, and that your foreign government employer's country provides equivalent tax-free treatment to US employees providing similar services in that country.

Many agreements establishing international organizations include a provision that can exempt your salary from US income tax. If you are employed in the US by an international organization, first check whether the international agreement under which you are working includes such a provision, and whether you qualify under that provision. Generally, these provisions do not exempt the salary of US citizens and residents as defined by tax law.

If the international organization you work for does not have a tax exemption clause in its international agreement and you are not a U.S. citizen (or if you are a U.S. citizen but also a citizen of the Philippines), you can exempt your salary from income tax under U.S. law. However, please see the section on Foreign Nationals (English) who maintain their immigration (legal permanent resident) status for special rules that may affect your eligibility for this exemption. The exemption provisions under U.S. tax law apply only to current employees of international organizations, not to former employees. Retirement benefits received by former employees of international organizations residing in the United States do not qualify for the exemption discussed here. This exemption does not apply to independent contractors. The common law rules apply to determine whether you are an employee or an independent contractor. Please see Publication 1779 (English) and Publication 15-A (English). To qualify for the exemption, you must be able to demonstrate that you meet the requirements of the international organization agreement or the U.S. tax law. You should know the clause number of the tax exemption provision in the international organization agreement (if any) and the number of the executive order that designates the organization as an international organization.

If you sign a waiver under Section 247(b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act (USCIS Form I-508) to retain your status as a legal permanent resident (Green Card), you will no longer be eligible for tax-free treatment under the US tax code from the date of filing the waiver. If you are an employee of a foreign government or international organization holding a Green Card, to qualify for tax-free treatment under the US tax code, you must also be able to provide USCIS written evidence that you have not signed and filed USCIS Form I-508.

If you are in one of the above categories (1) or (2) and have claimed an exemption under Section 247(b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act, you must obtain an exit permit. Even if your income is exempt from U.S. income tax by virtue of a tax treaty, a consular agreement, or an international agreement, this is still true.

Holders of F-1, F-2, H-3, H-4, J-1, J-2, or Q visas, and foreign students, industrial trainees, and exchange visitors, and their spouses and children, who have not received income from the United States (excluding travel, maintenance, and study expenses paid from United States sources) during the period of their visa status, and who have not received any services or lodging related to the study or training for which they are in the United States, and who have not received any income from employment authorized by the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS), or from interest income on deposits that are not linked to a valid business or trade relationship with the United States.

Foreign students, including those who enter the United States on an M-1 or M-2 visa and who do not receive income from a U.S. source during the period of their visa, are not required to report the following types of income: income from employment authorized by the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) or interest income from deposits that are not linked to a U.S. trade or business. (See Chapter 3, Interest Income.)

Specific other non-resident aliens who have not received taxable income during the tax year or the preceding tax year up to the date of departure. If the IRS has reason to believe that the alien received taxable income and that the income will affect the collection of taxes after departure, it may require the alien to obtain an exit or departure permit. The following are in this category of aliens: 1. Foreign military trainees who entered the United States under the sponsorship of the Department of Defense and left the United States under official military movement orders; 2. Foreign visitors who entered the United States with a B-1 visa, or with a B-1 and B-2 visa and who stayed in the United States or its territories for less than 90 days during the tax year; 3. If you bring documents and papers related to your income and time in the United States to the IRS office, you will get your departure or departure permit faster. If applicable, bring the following documents with you. 1. Your passport and alien registration card or visa. 2. Copies of your tax returns for the past 2 years. If you have been in the United States for less than 2 years, bring copies of your tax returns for that period. 3. Receipts for income taxes paid on these tax returns. 4. Receipts, bank records, canceled checks, and other documents that prove your deductions, business expenses, and the amount of your dependents. 5. A statement from each employer showing the wages and taxes withheld from your salary for the year. If you are self-employed, you must bring a statement of your income and expenses for the year up to the date of your departure. 6. Estimated tax payments for the past year and this year. 7. Documents showing any gains or losses from the sale of personal property and/or real estate (including capital assets and commodities). 8. Documents relating to any scholarships or grants, including: 1. Proof of the sponsor, source, and purpose of the scholarship or grant. 2. Copies of the application and approval for the scholarship or grant. 3. Reports of payments made, and your duties and obligations under the scholarship or grant. 4. A list of any past scholarships. 9. Documents showing that you are eligible for any special tax treaty benefits. 10. Documents showing the date you left the United States, such as a ticket. 11. Documents verifying your U.S. tax identification number (TIN), such as a Social Security card or a CP 565 notice from the IRS showing your personal tax identification number (ITIN).

If you must obtain an exit permit, you must file Form 2063 or Form 1040-C. IRS office employees can help you file these forms. Both forms have a 'Compliance Certification' block. The Compliance Certification signed by an agent in the Field Assistance Area Office proves that you have fulfilled your U.S. tax obligations based on the information available. The signed Form 1040-C or the attached document to Form 2063 is your exit permit.

If you must obtain an exit permit and you are not eligible to file Form 2063, you must file Form 1040-C. Generally, all income received or reasonably expected to be received during the tax year in which you depart and until the date of departure must be reported on Form 1040-C, and the tax shown on the form must be paid. If you pay the tax shown on Form 1040-C and you file all your tax returns and pay all taxes due for prior years, you will be issued an exit permit. However, the IRS may permit you to make a bond instead of paying the tax for a specific year. See Bond in the following text. An exit permit issued under these conditions is valid only for the departure for which it is issued.

If you provide the IRS with information that satisfies the IRS that you intend to return to the United States and that your departure will not jeopardize the collection of income tax, you can obtain a departure or departure permit by filing Form 1040-C, without paying the tax shown on the form. However, you must file all required income tax returns for all income not previously filed and pay all taxes shown on those returns. The Form 1040-C signed by you must include all income received during the entire departure year and reasonably expected to be received. The departure or departure permit issued by Form 1040-C may be used for any departure during the year in which it is issued. However, if the IRS believes that the collection of income tax is in doubt, it can cancel the use of the departure or departure permit in any subsequent departure.

Generally, you must pay the tax shown on Form 1040-C. However, if you have paid all the taxes you owe from previous years, you can make a payment bond in lieu of paying the income tax shown on Form 1040-C, or if the filing deadline for the return has not yet passed, you can file a return for the previous year. The payment bond must equal the amount of interest the IRS charges on the tax due on the due date of the return. You can get information about the bond and form from the IRS office.

'Work period' means the period of time from the first day you actually work in the U.S. to the last day you actually work in the U.S. in the year.
