If you use the expected amount of compensation to calculate your loss from an accident or theft, you may need to adjust your tax return for the tax year in which you actually receive the compensation. This section describes the adjustments you may need to make. If you paid for repairs that deteriorated the concrete foundation of your personal residence, and claimed a deduction on your original or amended federal individual income tax return for the repairs, and the Connecticut Foundation Solutions Indemnity Company (CFSIC) paid you (or the contractor representing you) some or all of the payment, you must include some or all of the payment in your gross income. See Announcement 2020-5, 2020-19 I.R.B. 796 (available at IRS.gov/irb/2020-19IRB#ANN-2020-5 (English)).

If the amount of compensation you later receive exceeds your expectation, you may need to include the extra amount in your gross income in the year you receive the extra amount after you claim the loss deduction. However, if any part of the original deduction amount did not reduce your tax for the prior year, do not include that part of the compensation amount in your gross income. You do not need to recalculate your tax for the year you claimed the deduction. See Publication 525, Tax Guide for Estate and Gift Tax and Estate and Gift Tax Return Preparers, at page 15 to see how much extra compensation amount to include in your gross income.
If the amount of compensation you receive in the future exactly matches your expectations, you do not have to include any compensation in your income, nor can you deduct any additional losses.

You can deduct losses from accidents or theft of inventory, including items you hold for sale to customers, in two ways. One way is to deduct the losses by properly reporting your beginning and ending inventory, by increasing the cost of goods sold to deduct the losses. Do not report this loss again as an accident or theft loss. If you suffer a loss due to the increase in cost of goods sold, include any insurance or other compensation you receive in total income. The other way is to deduct the loss individually. If you deduct the loss individually, then adjust your beginning inventory or purchases downward and deduct the affected inventory items from the cost of goods sold. Deduct the loss by the amount of the compensation you receive. Do not include the compensation in total income. If you do not receive the compensation before the end of the year, in the event you have a reasonable expectation of receiving the compensation, you may not claim the loss.

If you are liable for damage to the property you rent due to an accident, your loss is the amount you must pay to repair the property minus any insurance or other compensation you receive or expect to receive.

You can use the appraised value of your property that you used to obtain a federal loan (or a federal loan guarantee) because of the disaster to determine the amount of your disaster loss. For more information about the disaster, see Disaster Loss.

Repairs to damaged property are not part of the loss from an accident. Cleaning up after an accident is not counted either. However, if you meet all of the following conditions, you can use the cost of cleaning up or repairing after the accident as a standard for calculating the fair market value decrease. Repairs have actually been completed. Repairs must be made in order to restore the property to its condition before the accident occurred. Repairs are not expensive. Repairs only address the damaged portion. The value of the property after repairs does not exceed the value of the property before the accident.

The cost of restoring the landscape to its original state after an accident may indicate a decrease in fair market value. You may be able to calculate your loss by considering your outlay in the following areas: Remove destroyed or damaged trees and shrubs, subtract any residual value you received. Pruning and other measures taken to protect damaged trees and shrubs. You must replant to restore the property to its approximate pre-accident value.

Books published by various car organizations that list car manufacturers and models may help calculate the value of your car. You can use the retail value of the car listed in the book, and adjust it by factors such as mileage and condition of the car, to determine the value of your car. These prices are not official, but they may help determine value and suggest relative prices so you can compare with current sales and models in your area. If your car is not listed in the book, determine its value from other sources. The trade-in value quoted by a dealer for your car is usually not a good measure of its true value.

Any losses determined by the safe harbor method must be reduced by the value of any repairs provided to you by a third party (e.g., work done by volunteers or work done by donations). In addition, any insurance, indemnity, or other compensation you receive must be deducted from your losses.

Please attach a statement to Form 4684 showing the amount of your casualty loss determined using Tax Guide 2018-08. Include the specific safe harbor method used. When completing Form 4684, do not enter the amount in the fifth line or sixth line for each property. Instead, enter the amount determined under the applicable safe harbor method in the seventh line. For losses from Harvey, Irma, and Maria, see Tax Guide 2018-09, 2018-2 I.R.B. 290, to learn about the cost index safe harbor method.

Personal-use residential real property is typically real property owned by an individual that is damaged by an accident, including improvements, and that contains at least one personal residence. If any part of a personal residence is used as a rental property or includes a family office used for trade or business or for a profit-making transaction, it is not included in personal residence. For more information, see Tax Procedure Guide 2018-08. The following are the safe-harbor methods for personal-use residential real property provided by Tax Procedure Guide 2018-08. Estimate repair cost method. Minimum method. Insurance method. Federal disaster declaration — contractor safe-harbor. Federal disaster declaration — disaster loan valuation.

The insurance safe harbor method allows you to calculate the amount of the decrease in the fair market value of your personal residential real estate based on the estimates of loss described in the reports prepared by the owner or flood insurance company. These reports must list the estimated loss you suffered due to property damage or destruction.

If the loss occurs in a disaster area and is caused by a federal disaster declaration, you can use the contractor safe harbor method or the disaster loan assessment method. Under the contractor safe harbor method, you can use the repair contract price specified in the contract prepared by an independent and licensed contractor to determine the amount of the decrease in the fair market value of your personal use residential real estate. Unless you are bound by a contract you and the contractor have signed and the contractor has specified the itemized costs of restoring your personal use residential real estate to its pre-loss condition, the safe harbor method does not apply to you.

In the Disaster Loan Assessment Safe Harbor method, you can use a prepared assessment of your estimated loss in a federal disaster to determine the amount of the decrease in the fair market value of your principal residence. You can use a prepared assessment of your estimated loss in a federal disaster to determine the amount of the decrease in the fair market value of your principal residence.

Personal property generally includes tangible personal property owned by an individual and not used in trade or business. Personal property does not include items that retain or increase in value over time or certain other types of property. For more information, see Tax Procedure Guide 2018-08. The personal property safe harbor method is the minimum federal disaster declaration amount and the replacement cost safe harbor method.

The cost of protecting your property from accidents or theft is not part of the loss from accidents or theft. The amount you spend on insurance or to protect your home from storms is not part of your loss. If the property is business property, these costs can be deducted as business expenses. If you make permanent improvements to your property to protect it from accidents or theft, add the cost of these improvements to the base amount of your property. An example of this is the cost of a flood-prevention levee.

In determining your loss, do not consider the sentimental value. If family heirlooms, heirlooms, or mementos are damaged, destroyed, or stolen, your loss must be calculated based on their FMV and subject to your adjusted base amount.

Your property is not taken into account because it is located in or near an area that has suffered an accident or may suffer an accident again. Your property is only considered lost if it has actually been damaged by an accident. However, if your home is located in a federal disaster area, please see the discussion of disaster losses in the text below.

Photographs taken after an incident will help to show the condition and value of the property after damage. Photos showing the condition of the property after repairs, repairs or replacements may also be helpful. Valuation is used to calculate the fair market value decrease caused by an accident or theft. For information on valuation, see the previous section Valuation, which is included in Calculating the decrease in fair market value — Items to consider. Photos and valuation costs of property damaged by an accident are not included in the loss. They are costs used to determine your tax obligations. From 2018 to 2025 tax years, they can no longer be claimed as a miscellaneous deduction.

If you have more income than losses, subtract your losses from your income. The difference is treated as a capital gain and must be reported on Schedule D (Form 1040). The 10% rule does not apply to your income. If your losses are not from a federal government-declared disaster, see the instructions for line 14 in the instructions for Form 4684.

When calculating the loss of your personal-use real property, you must consider all improvements (such as buildings and landscaping trees and improvements on the land where the improvements are located).

Property used for personal purposes and property used for business or income-generating purposes are treated separately for the purpose of determining the amount of loss or theft that may be deducted. You must calculate each loss separately because losses attributable to each use are calculated differently. When calculating each loss, you must allocate the total cost or base amount, the fair market value before and after the loss, and the insurance or other compensation received for the business and personal use of the property. The 100-dollar rule and the 10-percent rule apply only to losses of property used for personal purposes.

The amount you receive includes any money, plus the value of any property you receive, minus any expenses you incur to obtain compensation. It also includes any compensation for any property that is damaged, destroyed, or stolen, and any mortgage or other lien on the property used to pay for the damage.

If you receive income from the destruction of your principal residence, you can generally deduct that income from your income, just as you would if you sold or bought a house. You can deduct up to $250,000 (up to $500,000 if you file a joint return) of the income. To deduct the income, you generally must have owned the residence for at least 5 years before it was destroyed and have lived in it as your principal residence for at least 2 years. For more information, see Publication 523. If you have income that exceeds the amount you can deduct, but you buy replacement property, you can defer reporting the excess income. See Deferring Income below.

Generally, you must report your compensation income for the year you receive it. However, if you meet certain requirements and choose to defer reporting the income based on the rules explained in Deferring Income, you do not have to report the income. To learn how to report income, see How to Report Income. If you have other personal-use property accident or theft losses (explained below) in addition to the personal-use property accident or theft losses you choose to defer reporting, when you calculate your accident or theft loss deduction amount, you do not consider the income you defer reporting. See the 10% rule, which is explained in the limits section above.

If you receive property similar to or in the same service or use as the stolen or damaged property as compensation, do not report the gain. Your new property's base is usually the same as the adjusted base of the property it replaces. If you receive money or other property as compensation, you generally must report the gain from the stolen or damaged property. However, if you purchase property similar to or in the same service or use as the stolen or damaged property within the specified replacement period, you can choose to defer reporting the gain, discussed below. If you purchase the controlling interest (at least 80%) in a company that owns property similar to or in the same service or use as the stolen or damaged property, you can also choose to defer reporting the gain. See Controlling interest in a corporation. If you have gain from damaged property, you can defer reporting the gain as long as you restore the property to its original condition with the compensation. To defer reporting all the gain, your cost of replacing the property must be at least equal to the amount of the compensation. If the cost of replacing the property is less than the amount of the compensation, you must include the gain in your income, but only to the extent of the unused compensation.

Under this rule, parents and children, siblings, individuals who own more than 50% of the issued shares of the company, and two partnerships that own more than 50% of the capital or profits of a C corporation are considered related persons. For more information on related persons, see Unallowable losses, which is in Section 544, Chapter 2, of the 2nd edition of the Tax Guide for Canada.

You must purchase a substitute property for a specific purpose of replacing a property that has been destroyed or stolen. Property received as a gift or by inheritance does not qualify. You do not have to use the money you receive from an insurance company for the old property to purchase a substitute property. If you spend the money you receive from an insurance company on other purposes and then borrow money to purchase a substitute property, you may still postpone reporting the gain if you meet other requirements.

If the compensation you receive for a destroyed principal residence exceeds the amount you can exclude from your income (see Principal Residence destroyed, which is discussed in the Calculating income section above), you can defer reporting excess income by purchasing an alternative property that is similar or related in service or use. If you defer reporting all of your excess income, the cost of the alternative property must be at least equal to the amount you received for the destruction, minus the amount of income excluded. In addition, if you defer reporting any part of your income under these rules, you will be treated as having owned and used the alternative property as your principal residence during the period you owned and used the destroyed property as your principal residence.

If you sell timber that has fallen in an accident (such as a strong wind, an earthquake, or a volcanic eruption) and use the proceeds to buy standing timber (rather than land), this qualifies as an alternative property. If you buy the standing timber within the specified replacement period, you can postpone reporting the income.

You can replace property with the holding rights of a company that has property similar to or related to your damaged, destroyed, or stolen property in service or use. If the cost of the stock that provides you with the holding rights is at least as much as the amount of money (compensation) you receive for your property, you can postpone reporting your entire income. If you own stock that represents at least 80% of all voting stock of all classes and at least 80% of all other stock, you have holding rights.

The delay is usually limited to no more than one year. The scarcity of the replacement property or the high market value of the property to be replaced is not sufficient to justify the approval of the delay. If your replacement property is under construction and you clearly state that you cannot complete the construction within the replacement period, you may be granted a delay.

You can delay reporting your income from an accident or theft by choosing to report it on your tax return in the year you receive the insurance payout or other compensation that creates the income. If the stolen or damaged property is owned by a partnership or corporation, only the partnership or corporation can choose to delay reporting the income.

You should attach a statement to your tax return for the year you received the income. The statement should include the following. Date and details of the accident or theft. Any insurance compensation or other compensation you received from the accident or theft. How you calculated the income.

If you purchased an alternative asset before filing your tax return in the year you received the income, your return should also include detailed information on the following. Alternative asset. Deferred income. Adjusted basis reflecting deferred income. Any income you report as income.

In either of the following situations, you must file an amended return (form 1040-X) for the tax year in which you received the income. You did not receive alternative property within the required replacement period and extension period. In the amended return, you must report the income and pay any additional tax due. You received alternative property within the required replacement period and extension period, but the cost was less than the amount you received from the accident or theft. In the amended return, you must report the non-deferred portion of the income and pay any additional tax due.

If the insurance or other compensation you receive exceeds your adjusted basis in your destroyed or stolen property, you will have a gain from the accident or theft. You must include this gain in your income for the year you receive the compensation, unless you choose to defer reporting the gain, as discussed earlier.

If you rent property from others, you can deduct the loss of that property in the year in which you determine the liability for the loss. Even if the loss occurs in a different year or the year in which you fulfill your obligation to make a claim is different, this is still true. You are not entitled to a deduction until your obligation under the lease can be determined with reasonable accuracy. Your obligation can be determined when the claim is settled, adjudicated or abandoned.

This section discusses special rules for losses declared by the federal government. It contains information on when you can deduct losses, how to file a claim, how to handle your home in the disaster area, and which tax deadlines can be extended. It also lists the phone numbers for the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA). (See the contact information for the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) in the text below.) Disaster losses are losses that occur in a disaster area declared by the President of the United States under the Stafford Act, which can be attributed to a disaster declared by the federal government. A disaster area includes a place that requires public or private assistance (or both). A federal disaster declaration includes a major disaster or an emergency declaration. The list of areas that require public or private assistance (or both) under the Stafford Act can be found at FEMA.gov/Disasters (English).
If your portion of the federal disaster loan is forgiven under the Stafford Act, it is considered compensation for the loss. The forgiveness will reduce your loss of accident deduction.

If disaster relief grants received under the Stafford Act are used to help you meet the necessary expenses or severe needs for medical, dental, housing, personal property, transportation, or burial expenses, do not include them in your income. Do not deduct these disaster relief grants as compensation for an accident loss or medical expenses. If an accident loss is specially compensated by the grant, and you receive the grant after deducting the accident loss in the year following the accident, see the discussion of compensation received after deducting losses in the preceding section. Unemployment compensation under the Stafford Act is taxable unemployment relief.

Companies that receive and use grants from state plans to compensate for property damage or destruction caused by disasters are not allowed to treat the grants as general benefits, gifts, or qualified disaster relief (discussed below), or as an investment in capital from which income is excluded. However, if a company purchases eligible replacement property within a specified period, the company may elect to defer reporting the income realized from the grant. Please refer to the section on Deferring Income for more information on the applicable rules.

The eligible disaster assistance also includes amounts paid by the federal, state, or local government to individuals affected by the declared disaster. These amounts must be paid from government funds, based on the need of the individual or family, rather than on the basis of service rendered. Assistance provided to businesses is generally not eligible.

Under the Stafford Act or the National Flood Insurance Act (effective April 15, 2005), eligible disaster relief payments are not included in income. These are payments you receive as a property owner to reduce the risk of damage to your property in the future. After using these payments, you cannot increase your property base by using them, nor can you claim a deduction or credit.

Generally, if you sell or otherwise dispose of property, unless the property is your principal residence, you must report any gain or loss for tax purposes. You report the gain or deduct the loss on your tax return for the year in which you realize the gain or loss. (You cannot deduct a loss from the sale of personal-use property, unless the loss is from an accidental event, as described above.) However, if you dispose of property by disaster relief sale to a federal, state, or local government or Indian tribal government, and you purchase a qualifying replacement property within a specified time, you may be able to defer reporting the gain for a specified period. See the discussion of  deferred gain  in this chapter for the rules that apply.

If the IRS delays filing deadlines, the following taxpayers are eligible for the delay. Any individual whose principal residence is located in the affected area. Any business entity or sole proprietor whose principal place of business is located in the affected area. Any individual who is a relief worker and is providing assistance in the affected area. Any individual, business entity or sole proprietor whose records are needed to meet the filing deadline for the delay and who maintains those records in the affected area. The principal residence or principal place of business need not be located in the affected area. Any estate or trust that possesses tax records necessary to meet the filing deadline for the delay and who maintains those records in the affected area. The spouse of a taxpayer who is eligible for the delay. Any individual, business entity or sole proprietor who maintains tax records necessary to meet the filing deadline for the delay and who maintains those records in the affected area, but who is not located in the affected area. Any individual who visits the affected area and suffers injury as a result of the disaster. Any other individual, business entity or sole proprietor determined by the IRS to be affected by a federal disaster declaration.
The IRS may reduce the interest and penalties charged on underpaid income taxes during the filing extension period.

Disaster year is the tax year in which you suffered a loss due to a federal disaster. Generally, disaster losses are continuous in the tax year in which the disaster occurred. However, disaster losses may also be continuous in the tax year following the disaster. For example, if there is a reasonable prospect of recovery, then any part of the loss that is not recovered in a reasonable amount of time may not be allowed.

You generally must deduct accidents incurred in a disaster year. However, if you suffer an accident in an area that requires public or personal assistance (or both) as a result of a federal disaster, you may choose to deduct the loss on your tax return or amended return for the tax year immediately preceding the disaster year. If you make this choice, the loss will be treated as occurring in the previous year. A list of areas requiring public or personal assistance (or both) is available on the Federal Emergency Management Agency website, FEMA.gov/Disasters (English). You must make your election to deduct disaster-related accident losses no later than six months after the normal due date of your disaster year return (original or amended) or before the due date of the return for the tax year immediately preceding the disaster year. If you are a calendar year taxpayer, you must amend your 2023 return by October 15, 2025, to claim a loss incurred in 2024.

If you filed your tax return for the previous year, you can choose to report a disaster loss on your tax return for that year by filing an amended tax return. You can report a disaster loss on Form 1040-X. (See How to Report a Loss on Form 1040-X in this publication.) If you choose to do so, you must report the disaster loss on Form 4684, Part D, Line 1, and attach it to your disaster loss deduction tax return or amended tax return for the year you are reporting the disaster loss. You must make the election to deduct the loss before the normal filing deadline for the tax year in which you filed your original tax return for the disaster year (not extended). For individual calendar-year taxpayers, the deadline to make the election to report a disaster loss on your 2023 tax return is October 15, 2025. See Form 4684, Instructions, for more information about how to report these losses on your original or amended 2023 tax return.

If you want to revoke your election to deduct federal government-declared disaster losses for the 2024 disaster year, you must file Form 4684, Part D, Section 2, for the 2023 tax year. Attach the completed D section to your modified return for the previous year (that is, the modified 2023 return you filed to revoke the 2024 disaster year election). You must file your modified return to revoke the election within 90 days after the deadline for making the election and before you file your return for the year in which you claimed the disaster loss. Your modified return (revoking the previous disaster loss election) should recalculate your tax liability after the election is revoked. You must pay or arrange to pay any taxes and interest due as a result of the revocation.

Eligible disaster losses also include personal accident losses or theft losses of personal property used for personal purposes caused by the following: a major disaster declared by the President pursuant to Section 401 of the Stafford Act; Hurricane Harvey; Hurricane Harvey; Hurricane Irma; Hurricane Maria; 2017 and 2018 California wildfires; a major disaster declared by the President pursuant to Section 401 of the Stafford Act, occurring on or after January 1, 2018, and continuing through January 19, 2020 (except for losses attributable to the 2018 California wildfires for which a waiver has been granted); and a major disaster declared by the President on or after January 1, 2020, and before February 10, 2025. In addition, the disaster must have an incident period that begins on or after December 28, 2019, and ends before January 11, 2025.

If your home is located in a disaster area declared by the federal government, your state or local government may order you to demolish or move it, because the disaster makes it unsafe to live there. If this happens, treat the loss of value as an accidental loss caused by the disaster. Your state or local government must issue an order requiring you to demolish or move your home within 120 days of the area being declared a disaster. Calculate your loss in the same way as you would an accidental loss of personal-use property. (See the section on Calculating your loss earlier in this publication.) When determining the amount of the decrease in fair market value, use the value of your home before the accident and its fair market value after the accident.

EIC is a tax credit for people who work and have low earnings of less than $66,819. Tax credits usually mean you have more money in your pocket. They can reduce the amount of taxes you owe. EIC may also give you a refund.
No, if you are at least 25 but not yet 65 and your labor income is less than $18,591 (for married filing jointly, $25,511), you can get EIC without a qualifying child. See Chapter 3.

Your adjusted gross income (AGI) must also be less than the amount just listed for you. For more information, see Rules 1 Limit and Rule 15. Investment income. Your maximum amount of investment income that you can own and still be eligible for the exemption is $11,600. See Rule 6—Your investment income must be $11,600 or less.

Your Adjusted Gross Income (AGI) must be less than: If you have three or more qualifying children with valid SSNs, $59,899 (married filing jointly $66,819), If you have two qualifying children with valid SSNs, $55,768 (married filing jointly $62,688), If you have one qualifying child with a valid SSN, $49,084 (married filing jointly $56,004), or If you have no qualifying children with valid SSNs, $18,591 (married filing jointly $25,511).

If you are married but eligible to file as head of household or as a separate taxpayer under the special rules for married taxpayers separated under the laws of a state that has community property laws (see Rule 3), and you reside in a state that has community property laws, your adjusted gross income includes the portion of your and your spouse's wages that must be included in your total income. This is different from the community property rules applicable to Rule 7.

To claim EIC, you (and your spouse, if you file a joint return) must have a valid Social Security Number (SSN) issued by the Social Security Administration (SSA) by the due date of your 2024 tax return (including any extensions). Your eligible children must have a valid SSN by the due date of your return or before to be able to claim higher EIC benefits for that child. If you have at least one child who qualifies to claim EIC, but that child does not have a valid SSN by the due date of your return or before, if you meet other conditions, you may be eligible to claim EIC only for yourself. If one or more of your children do not have a valid SSN by the due date of your return or before, to get information about how to complete Schedule EIC, see Schedule EIC. An SSN is valid for EIC unless it is issued after the due date of your 2024 tax return (including any extensions) or it is issued solely for the purpose of applying for or receiving a federal benefit that does not authorize you to work. Medical assistance is an example of a federal benefit. If you, your spouse, or your child has a Social Security card that has the words “Not valid for employment” printed on it, and you, your spouse, or your child’s immigration status changes so that the individual becomes a U.S. citizen or permanent resident, request the SSA to issue a Social Security card without the words “Not valid for employment” printed on it.
If you are a US citizen when you receive a Social Security Number, you have a valid Social Security Number.

If your SSN is on a Social Security Card that says "Valid for work only with INS authorization" or "Valid for work only with DHS authorization", then your SSN is only valid while the authorization is still valid.
If you are married, you usually have to file a joint tax return to claim EIC. However, there is a special rule for separated spouses.

If you are a non-tax resident at any time during the year, unless your filing status is married filing jointly, you cannot claim EIC. You can only use this filing status if your spouse is a U.S. citizen or tax resident and you choose to be treated as a U.S. resident. If you make this choice, you and your spouse will be taxed on worldwide income. If you need more information about how to make this choice, get Publication 519. If you are a non-tax resident for the entire year and your filing status is not married filing jointly, enter a «No» in the space next to line 27 (form 1040 or 1040-SR). See form 1040 instructions for nonresident aliens and dual-status residents for more information, including information about making the choice to treat your nonresident alien or dual-status alien spouse as a U.S. resident for the entire tax year.

If you file Form 2555, Foreign Income, you cannot claim EIC. You file these forms to exclude from your total income income earned abroad, or to deduct or exclude foreign housing amounts. U.S. territories are not considered foreign. See publication 54 for more information.

This benefit amount is called the 'EIC' because to qualify, you must work and have earned income. If you are married and file a joint return, at least one spouse works and has earned income, you meet this rule. If you are an employee, earned income includes all taxable income you receive from your employer. The information in Rule 15 can help you calculate your earned income amount. If you are self-employed or a statutory employee, you can calculate your earned income on Form 1040 Schedule B, the EIC work sheet.

Labor income includes all types of income. 1. Wages, salaries, tips, and other compensation to employees. Employee compensation is only labor income when it is taxable. Non-taxable employee compensation, such as certain dependent care benefits and adoption benefits, is not labor income. However, non-taxable combat pay has an exception, you can choose to include it in labor income, as described in this chapter later. 2. Net self-employment income. 3. Total income received as an employee.
Your wages, salaries, and tips from work are reported in box 1a of your Form W-2. You must report this information on line 1 of your Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR.

Other types of labor income not reported in box 1 of your W-2, including household employee wages, unreported tip income, certain federal health insurance tax exemption payments (if you choose to include non-taxable amounts in your income for purposes of claiming EIC), taxable foster care payments, adoption assistance provided by your employer on Form 8839, wages reported on Form 8919, and other earned income. You should report these amounts on lines 1b through 1h of your 1040 or 1040-SR.

As part of the pastor's salary, housing rent or housing allowance provided to the pastor is usually not subject to income tax, but is included in self-employment net income. For this reason, it is included in the labor income of the EIC (except for the description of the approved Form 4361 or Form 4029).

As a benefit paid to you for a strike or lockout, including the fair market value (not a gift) of cash and other property, is generally taxable. If a strike or lockout benefit is taxable, it is generally treated as earned income. You should report the amount of your taxable strike or lockout benefit on line 1h of your Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR.

Whether or not you have a Form 4361, any income you receive as a minister of the gospel is considered employment income. This includes wages, salary, tips, and other taxable employee compensation. If you have a Form 4361, non-taxable housing allowance or non-taxable rent on your home are not considered employment income. In addition, income you receive as a non-employee minister is not considered employment income. Examples include fees for officiating weddings and honorariums for speaking engagements.

Whether or not you have a Form 4029, all wages, salaries, tips, and other taxable employee compensation are considered labor income. However, amounts you receive as a self-employed person are not labor income. In addition, do not deduct losses from Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR, line 1a through 1h, from Form C or Form F when calculating your income.

If you retire because of a disability, your taxable disability payments before you reach your minimum retirement age will be considered as earned income. If you are not disabled, your minimum retirement age is usually the earliest age at which you can receive retirement or annuity benefits. You must report your taxable disability payments on line 1h of Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR until you reach your minimum retirement age. From the day after you reach your minimum retirement age, your payments will be treated as retirement income and not as earned income. Report your taxable retirement income on lines 5a and 5b of Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR.

The payments you receive from your disability insurance policy are not considered earned income. It doesn't matter if you've reached the minimum retirement age. If you received the policy through your employer, the amount may be reported in box 12 of your Form W-2, code J.

Examples of non-labor income include interest and dividends, pensions and annuities, social security and railroad retirement benefits (including disability benefits), alimony and child support, welfare benefits, workers' compensation benefits, unemployment insurance benefits (including unemployment compensation), exempt support payments, and veteran's benefits, including VA rehabilitation payments. Do not include any of these items in your labor income.

Non-taxable work benefits payments are not labor income under the EIC. These are cash payments received from state or local public assistance agencies that administer the federal Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) program, in exchange for certain work activities, such as (1) work experience activities (including rehabilitation or repair of public housing) if there are insufficient private sector employment opportunities, or (2) community service program activities.

If you are married but eligible to file as head of household or as a separate taxpayer under the special rules for married taxpayers who are separated (see Rule 3), and you reside in a state that has community property laws, your EIC does not include any amount that your spouse is considered to be yours under those laws. That amount is not labor income for the EIC, even if you must include it in your total income on your income tax return. Your labor income includes all of your income, even if under your state's community property laws, part of it is considered to be your spouse's.

If you are a registered domestic partner in Nevada, Washington, or California, the same rules apply to you. Your EIC labor income does not include any income earned by your partner. Your labor income includes all income earned by you. For more information, see Publication 555,.

If you are receiving Social Security retirement or disability benefits when you receive any payment under the Long-term Conservation Program, your Long-term Conservation Program payment is not considered earned income for the EIC.

For EIC, if someone is placed with you by an authorized placement agency or by any court of competent jurisdiction, or by order of any other court, then that person is your foster child. Authorized placement agencies include: state or local government agencies, tax-exempt organizations authorized by the state, and Indian tribal governments or organizations authorized by Indian tribal governments to place Indian children.

Schools may be elementary, secondary, high school, college, university, or technical, trade, or mechanical schools. However, job training courses, correspondence schools, and schools that offer courses only via the Internet are not considered EIC schools.
As part of regular school classes and practical training courses, students engaged in private-sector education-industry cooperation are considered full-time students.

If both of the following conditions apply, your child will be considered permanently and totally disabled. 1. Due to physical or mental conditions, unable to engage in any substantial gainful activity. 2. The doctor determines the condition has lasted or is expected to last at least one year or may result in death.

Substantial earning activities are work that is performed for compensation or profit, or in circumstances where compensation or profit is typically received for work. Full-time work (or part-time work, if convenient for the employer) that is at least at the minimum wage in a competitive work environment indicates that the child can engage in substantial earning activities. Substantial earning activities are not performed to care for oneself or the family. They are not about hobbies, institutional treatment or training, school attendance, clubs, social activities, and similar unpaid work. However, doing such work may indicate that the child can engage in substantial earning activities. The fact that a child has not worked for a period of time does not prove that the child cannot engage in substantial earning activities. For examples of substantial earning activities, see the instructions for Form 1040, Schedule R (Form 1040), line 17.

Your children must spend more than half of 2024 with you in the United States. Even if you pay most of your children's living expenses, you can't claim EIC for more than half of a year that your children don't live with you. The IRS may require you to provide documentation that you are living with each qualifying child. You may need to keep records of this purpose, including school and day care records, and other records showing your children's address.

If you and another person have the same qualifying child, but the other person is not eligible because he or she does not meet the requirements or his or her income or adjusted gross income is too high to claim EIC, you can treat the child as a qualifying child. See Examples 6 and 7. However, if the other person claims the child as a qualifying child for any of the five tax benefits listed above, you cannot treat the child as a qualifying child for EIC.

You must be between the ages of 25 and 65 at the end of 2024. If you are married and file a joint return, you or your spouse must be between the ages of 25 and 65 at the end of 2024. It doesn't matter which spouse meets the age test, only that one of you does. If you were born between December 31, 1959, and January 2, 2000, you meet the age test. If you are married and file a joint return, and either you or your spouse was born between December 31, 1959, and January 2, 2000, you meet the age test. If neither you nor your spouse meets the age test, you cannot claim EIC. Enter “No” (No) in the blank next to line 27 (form 1040 or 1040-SR).

You are a married individual who filed a joint tax return with your spouse who died in August 2024. Your age is 67. Your spouse will turn 65 in November 2024. Because your spouse died before turning 65, you meet the age test requirement.

A deceased taxpayer who is at least 25 but not yet 65 years old at the time of death is eligible for the age test. The taxpayer is considered to be 25 years old on the day before his or her 25th birthday. However, the age of 65 rule is different; the taxpayer is considered to be 65 years old on his or her 65th birthday. Even if the taxpayer was born before January 2, 2000, he or she will not be considered to be at least 25 years old at the end of 2024 unless he or she was at least 25 years old at the time of death.

If you are married and file a joint tax return, you usually cannot be claimed as a dependent by someone else. However, if you and your spouse file a joint return only to claim a refund of withheld income tax or to pay estimated taxes, then others may be able to claim you as a dependent. However, if you apply for EIC on your joint return, you and your spouse cannot be claimed as a dependent by anyone else.

If you are married and file a joint tax return, you are usually not eligible to be a qualifying child of another taxpayer. However, if you and your spouse file a joint return only to claim a refund of withheld income tax or to pay estimated tax, you may be a qualifying child of another taxpayer. However, if you claim the EIC on your joint return, you and your spouse are both not eligible to be a qualifying child of another taxpayer.

If your EIC was denied or reduced for any reason other than a mathematical error or a mistake in your handwriting in any year after 1996, you must attach Form 8862 to your next tax return to claim your EIC. You must also meet all the rules described in this publication to be eligible to claim your EIC.

If you need more information, please refer to the section in this chapter entitled Are you prohibited from filing an EIC for a period of time? Your date of denial of your EIC and the date you filed your 2024 tax return will impact whether you need to attach Form 8862 to your 2024 tax return or future tax returns. The following examples illustrate whether you need to file Form 8862 for 2024 or 2025.

If your EIC is denied or reduced due to a mathematical error or a mistake in your handwriting, do not attach Form 8862 to your next tax return. For example, if you made a mathematical error, the IRS can make a correction. If you did not provide the correct Social Security number, the IRS can deny your EIC. These types of errors are called mathematical errors or mistakes in handwriting.

If your EIC was denied after 1996 and it is determined that your mistake was due to carelessness or willful disregard of the rules, then you are disqualified from claiming EIC for the next 2 years. If your mistake was due to fraud, then you are disqualified from claiming EIC for the next 10 years. The date your EIC was denied and the date you file your 2024 tax return will determine the years you are disqualified from claiming EIC. The following examples illustrate the years you are disqualified from claiming EIC.

Jamie Smith is 63 years old and retired. Jamie received $7,000 in Social Security benefits this year and earned $17,000 in part-time income. Jamie also received $7,400 in taxable pension income. Jamie has no other income. Jamie's AGI is $24,400 (17,000 + 7,400). Jamie is unmarried and lived alone in the U.S. all year. Jamie cannot be claimed as a dependent on any other person's tax return. Jamie has no investment income and no qualifying children. Jamie reads the instructions for Form 1040. In Step 1, Jamie finds that his AGI ($24,400) is not less than $18,591, so Jamie is not eligible for EIC. Jamie completes the rest of Form 1040 and files it with the IRS.

Cameron and Jordan Grey have two children, ages 10 and 8. The children lived with Cameron and Jordan throughout 2024. Cameron's salary was $15,000, and Jordan's salary was $18,030. The Greys received $525 of interest from their savings account. They had no other income in 2024. Cameron and Jordan filed Form 1040 and Schedule 1. They want to determine if they are eligible for EIC, so they follow the instructions in Step 27 of the instructions for Schedule 1.

Cameron and Jordan entered $33,555 on line 11 of Form 1040. They both have valid and long-held Social Security Numbers (SSN). They are married and will file a joint tax return. Cameron and Jordan are not non-tax residents as defined by the tax code. Therefore, their answer to step 1 allows them to proceed to step 2.
Grey's only income from investments is $525. The amount is less than $11,600, so they answer the second question in step 2 as 'No' (No), and proceed to step 3.

Cameron and Jordan completed their work sheets as instructed. 1. Cameron and Jordan entered their total labor income ($33,030) in row 1. 2. They moved to the EIC table to find their benefit amount. They found their labor income of $33,030 in the range of $33,000 to $33,050. Because their two children had valid SSNs, they looked under the Married Filing Joint item in the row corresponding to 2 children and found the shown amount of $6,247. They entered $6,247 in row 2. 3. They entered their Adjusted Gross Income ($33,555) in row 3 and found that it was different from the amount in row 1. 4. They looked up $33,555 in the EIC table and entered the amount of $6,131 in row 5. 5. They entered $6,131 in row 6. This is the smaller of the amounts in row 2 ($6,247) and row 5 ($6,131). 6. The Greys entered $6,131 in row 27 of their Form 1040. They will now complete the EIC work sheet and attach it to their tax return. They will keep the EIC work sheet as a record.

After receiving all your pay and income statements (W-2, W-2G, 1099-R, 1099-MISC, 1099-NEC, etc.), unemployment compensation statements (mailed or digital format), other government payment statements (1099-G), and interest, dividends, and retirement income statements (1099), you have several options for filing and submitting your tax return. You can file your own tax return, check to see if you qualify for free tax preparation services, or hire a tax professional to prepare your tax return.

Taxpayers needing information about accessible services should call 833-690-0598. The accessible services hotline can answer questions about current and future accessible products and services that can be provided through alternative media formats (such as braille, large print, audio, etc.). The accessible services hotline does not have access to your IRS account. If you need help with tax laws, refunds or account-related issues, visit IRS.gov/LetUsHelp.

Through your online account, you can get a variety of information to help you during tax season. You can get copies, view recently filed tax returns, and get adjusted gross income. Go to IRS.gov/Account to set up or access your online account.

The safest and easiest way to get your refund is to file electronically and choose direct deposit, which securely transfers your refund directly to your financial account. Direct deposit also avoids the possibility of lost, stolen, damaged, or undeliverable checks to the IRS. 80% of taxpayers use direct deposit to get their refunds. If you don't have a bank account, go to IRS.gov/DirectDeposit to learn more about where to find a bank or credit union that offers online accounts.

If you qualify, you have the option of filing and submitting your tax return online or in your local community, including the following. File Online. File Online is a permanent option to file your personal federal tax return directly and securely online for free. File Online is an option for filers with relatively simple tax returns who report certain types of income and claim certain deductions. Although File Online is not used to file state tax returns, if you live in a participating state, File Online will guide you to use a state-supported tool that can be used to file and submit state tax returns for free. For more information, updates on the program, and frequently asked questions, visit IRS.gov/DirectFile. Free File. This program allows you to use free tax software or free fillable forms to prepare and file your federal individual income tax return. However, state tax returns may not be available through Free File. To see if you qualify for free online federal tax preparation, e-file, and direct deposit or payment options, visit IRS.gov/FreeFile. VITA. The Volunteer Income Tax Education (VITE) program provides free tax assistance to low- and moderate-income taxpayers, people with disabilities, and those with limited English proficiency who need help preparing their tax returns. To find out more about VITA, download the IRS2Go app for free, or call 800-906-9887. Senior Tax Counseling (TCE). The Tax Counseling for the Elderly (TCE) program provides free tax assistance to all taxpayers, especially those age 60 and older. TCE volunteers specialize in answering questions about retirement-related issues specific to seniors. To find out more about TCE, visit IRS.gov/TCE, or download the IRS2Go app for free. MilTax. Members of the U.S. Armed Forces and eligible veterans can use MilTax, a free tax service provided by the Department of Defense through Military OneSource. For more information, visit MilitaryOneSource.mil/MilTax. In addition, the IRS provides free fillable forms that can be filed online regardless of income.

The IRS will not contact taxpayers via email, text messages (including shortened links), phone calls or social media to request or verify personal or financial information. This includes requests for personal identification numbers (PINs), passwords or similar information for credit cards, bank accounts or other financial accounts. Visit the IRS Identity Theft Center webpage at IRS.gov/IdentityTheft for information about identity theft and data security for taxpayers, tax professionals and businesses. If your Social Security number is lost or stolen, or you suspect you are a victim of tax-related identity theft, you can learn what steps to take. Get an Identity Protection PIN (IP PIN). An Identity Protection PIN is a six-digit number assigned to taxpayers to help prevent their Social Security number from being used in tax-related identity theft. When you have an Identity Protection PIN, you can prevent others from using your Social Security number to file a tax return.

U.S. tax payments must be made in U.S. dollars to IRS. Does not accept digital assets. Visit IRS.gov/Payments for information on how to use one of the following payment options. Direct Pay: Pay your personal tax bill or estimated tax bill directly from your check or savings account without additional fees. Debit card, credit card, or digital wallet: Choose an approved payment processor to pay online or by phone. Electronic Funds Withdrawal: Provide instructions to pay when filing your federal tax return using tax preparation software or through a tax professional. Federal Electronic Payment System: This is the best option for businesses. You must register. Check or money order: Mail your payment to the address listed on your notice or instruction. Cash: You can pay your tax bill in cash at participating retail stores. Wire transfer: You may be able to make a same-day wire transfer from your financial institution. Contact your financial institution to determine feasibility, fees, and time frame.

Go to IRS.gov/Payments to learn more about your options. Apply for an Online Payment Agreement (IRS.gov/OPA) to make monthly payments to meet your tax obligations (if you can't pay your tax bill in full today). You will immediately receive a notification about whether your agreement has been approved after you complete the online process. Use the Online Offer in Compromise (OIC) Pre-Screening Tool (English) to see if you may be able to settle your tax debt for less than the amount you owe. For more information about the OIC, go to IRS.gov/OIC.

You may request a change of language preference by using Form LEP (1040 Schedule), which is available at irs.gov/forms. You may not immediately receive the communication in the language you requested. The IRS commitment to provide translations for LEP taxpayers is part of a multi-year plan to translate communications, including English notifications and correspondence, beginning in 2023. You will continue to receive communications, including English notifications and correspondence, until they are translated into your preferred language.

TAS can help you resolve problems you can't solve on your own with the IRS. Be sure to try to solve your problem with the IRS first, but if you can't, go to TAS. Our service is free. TAS helps all taxpayers (and their representatives), including individuals, businesses, and tax-exempt organizations. If your IRS problem results in financial difficulty, if you have tried but cannot solve your problem with the IRS, or if you think the IRS system, processes, or procedures are not working properly, you may be eligible for TAS assistance. To get help with general tax topics at any time, visit www.TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov (English). That website can help you with common tax problems and situations, such as what to do if you made a mistake on your tax return or if you received a notice from the IRS. TAS is committed to solving large-scale (systemic) problems that affect many taxpayers. You can report system problems at www.IRS.gov/SAMS. (Please do not include any personal identifying information.)
