Tax professionals first® (PPS). Tax professionals first® is a nationwide free hotline that provides professional assistance to tax professionals on account-related issues. The toll-free number is 1-866-860-4259. Annual Filing Season Program (AFSP) and Federal Tax Return Preparer List. The Annual Filing Season Program is a voluntary program that allows tax return preparers who are not attorneys, certified public accountants, or registered tax return preparers to have limited practice rights. The IRS issues an Annual Filing Season Program (AFSP) Completion Certificate to tax return preparers who complete a specified number of hours of continuing education during a specific tax year. Annual Filing Season Program participants do not have unlimited practice rights (unless they are also attorneys, certified public accountants, or registered tax return preparers). Their rights are limited to representing their own clients in filing and signing tax returns, and to communicating with IRS employees, customer service representatives, and similar IRS employees, including the Taxpayer Advocacy Service. They may not represent clients on whom they have not filed and signed tax returns, or on appeals or collection functions. For more information about the Annual Filing Season Program, visit IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/Annual-Filing-Season-Program (in English). To access an online searchable database of tax return preparers who have a tax preparer tax identification number, visit IRS.Treasury.gov/rpo (in English).

This document describes the people who can represent taxpayers in dealings with the IRS, and what kinds of forms or documents authorize someone to act on behalf of a taxpayer. Generally, attorneys, certified public accountants (CPA), and registered tax preparers can represent taxpayers in dealings with the IRS. Registered retirement plan consultants and actuaries can represent taxpayers in dealings with the IRS in the specific areas of IRS regulations described in Notice 230. In special and limited circumstances, other individuals such as unregistered tax preparers, family members, employees, and students can represent taxpayers in dealings with the IRS. For more information on who can represent taxpayers before the IRS, see Who Can Practice Before the IRS in the text that follows.
Many of the terms used in this publication, such as "registered tax preparer" and "practicing professional" are defined in the Glossary and listed at the end of this publication.

The following persons are subject to the regulations of Notice 230. However, any fully authorized individual (authorized representative) must be designated as the taxpayer's representative and file a written statement with the IRS, stating that he or she is authorized and qualified to represent a specific taxpayer. Form 2848 may be used for this purpose.

Because of their special relationship with taxpayers, the following individuals may, under the condition of providing satisfactory identification and authorization documents to represent the designated taxpayer with the Internal Revenue Service, except for the following (1) described situation. 1. Individual. An individual may represent himself or herself with the Internal Revenue Service and does not need to file a written qualification and authority statement. 2. Family. An individual may represent his or her immediate relatives. Immediate relatives include the individual's spouse, children, parents, brothers or sisters. 3. Officials. The officers of a true company (including the parent company, subsidiary or other affiliate company), association or organized group may represent the company, association or organized group. Governmental units, agencies or authorities' officers may represent the governmental units, agencies or authorities in carrying out their duties with the Internal Revenue Service. 4. Partners. General partners may represent the partnership with the Internal Revenue Service. 5. Employees. Formal full-time employees may represent their employer. The employer may be but is not limited to an individual, partnership, company (including the parent company, subsidiary or other affiliate company), association, trust, takeover, guardianship, estate, organized group, governmental units, agencies or authorities. 6. Trustees. Trustees (trustees, executors, personal representatives, administrators, takers over, guardians or guardians) act on behalf of the taxpayer as a taxpayer rather than as a representative. Please refer to Trustees in the section of No need for a power of attorney.

Students working at the Low Income Taxpayer Service Center (LITC) or the Student Tax Center Program (STCP) must obtain permission to represent themselves as a legal, business, or accounting major. Authorization requests must be sent to the Taxpayer Advocate Service. If approved, a letter will be issued granting the student special appearance and detailing any conditions related to the appearance. The student receiving the letter of authorization is typically able to represent the taxpayer in any manner consistent with the conditions outlined in the letter of authorization and must be under the direct supervision of an authorized individual who is able to practice before the IRS. If you intend to have a student represent you, review the letter of authorization and consult with your student, your supervisor, or the Taxpayer Advocate Service if you have any questions about the authorization terms.

Any lawyer who is not temporarily prohibited or terminated from practicing before the IRS and who is a member in good standing of the bar of any state, territory, commonwealth, federal district or U.S. territory or possession, or the District of Columbia, may practice before the IRS.
"English": "Any licensed preparer who is not currently suspended or terminated by the IRS may practice before the IRS.

Any licensed registered retirement plans counselor who is not temporarily prohibited or terminated from practicing before the IRS may practice before the IRS. The practice of a registered retirement plans counselor is limited to specific IRS regulations related to their area of expertise, primarily those governing employee retirement plans.

Any individual who is registered as an actuary with the Actuarial Registration Council and is not temporarily suspended or terminated from practice before the IRS may practice before the IRS. The practice of registered actuaries is limited to specific IRS regulations related to their area of expertise, primarily those governing employee retirement plans.

In specific cases, students in law schools or equivalent courses who provide tax services to low-income taxpayers and are supervised by practicing professionals may request authorization to represent taxpayers in dealings with the IRS. For more information, see the section on Special Authorization for Limited Practice in the text below.

"English": "Unregistered tax preparers are individuals who are not lawyers, certified public accountants, registered tax preparers, registered retirement plan administrators, or registered actuaries. Unregistered tax preparers prepare and sign tax returns for taxpayers or prepare tax returns without signing them (as indicated in the instructions for the tax return or by law). Unregistered tax preparers may only represent taxpayers in communication with IRS employees, customer service representatives, and similar IRS employees (including Taxpayer Advocate Service) and in examining the tax returns they prepared and signed before December 31, 2015. Unregistered tax preparers may not represent taxpayers before appeal officers, IRS officers, advisors, or similar IRS or Treasury Department officers or employees. Unregistered tax preparers may not represent taxpayers in signing settlement agreements, extending the time to assess or collect taxes, claiming exemptions, or signing any documents. If an unregistered tax preparer does not meet the limited representation requirements, you can authorize an unregistered tax preparer to examine and/or request your tax information by filing Form 8821. Filing Form 8821 will not authorize an unregistered tax preparer to represent you in communication with IRS employees. For more information, see Form

Generally, a person will lose his or her qualification to practice before the IRS in the following ways. Failure to meet the requirements for renewal (such as continuing professional education). As a registered tax preparer, the person's application to continue as a registered tax preparer is rendered invalid. Being temporarily prohibited or terminated from practicing by the Professional Responsibility Office for violating the provisions of Notice 230 or the standards. IRS 81-38 procedure. Losing his or her state license as an attorney or certified public accountant, regardless of the basis for the revocation of the license.

Individuals who are required to be placed in inactive retired status must not be eligible to practice before the IRS. They must continue to comply with all renewal requirements. They may restore to renewal status by submitting a renewal application and providing evidence that they have completed the continuing professional education hours required for their registration period.

All individuals practicing before the IRS are subject to disciplinary action and may be sanctioned for violating any provision of Notice 230. This includes making representations indicating incompetence or unprofessional conduct. For more information, see Uncompetence and Unprofessional Conduct in the text under Professional Responsibility. An individual who is temporarily suspended or terminated from practice before the IRS may not represent taxpayers in dealings with the IRS during the period of temporary suspension or termination. An individual who seeks reinstatement of his or her license may do so through the Professional Responsibility Office after the period of temporary suspension or the five-year period of termination (whichever is shorter). See the text under What is practice before the IRS? for more information. If an individual seeks reinstatement, he or she may not practice before the IRS until the Professional Responsibility Office approves reinstatement. The Professional Responsibility Office may grant reinstatement of an individual's license if: The individual's future conduct is unlikely to violate any provision of Notice 230. The grant of reinstatement would not be contrary to the public interest. The individual meets other conditions within a reasonable time.

The IRS website IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/Enrolled-Agents/Become-an-Enrolled-Agent (English) provides complete information on how to become an Enrolled Agent. For complete rules on obtaining the Annual Filing Season Program Record of Completion, see IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/General-Requirements-for-the-Annual-Filing-Season-Program-Record-of-Completion (English).

The rules governing practice before the IRS are published in Title 10, Subtitle A, Chapter 31 of the Code of Federal Regulations, and are distributed in electronic form in the Department of the Treasury Notice 230 (Notice 230). These rules can be found at IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/Circular-230-Tax-Professionals. Authorized tax professionals, including attorneys, certified public accountants, registered tax return preparers, registered retirement plan administrators, registered retirement plan consultants, or registered retirement plan agents (collectively, tax professionals), and appraisers are required to perform certain acts and are restricted from performing other acts. In addition, tax professionals may not engage in conduct that is detrimental to their reputation. Any tax professional who fails to comply with the practice rules or engages in incompetent or unprofessional conduct will be subject to discipline. In addition, unregistered tax return preparers must comply with the practice rules and conduct rules in order to exercise limited practice authority before the IRS. There are two sets of applicable specific rules, both of which are described in Notice 230: 1. Professional Responsibilities and Limitations (Notice 230 B Subpart B), and 2. Conduct that is considered to be incompetent or unprofessional (Notice 230 10.51 B Subpart B).

Individuals subject to Notice 230 are required to immediately comply with the appropriate and lawful requests of IRS officials or employers for the records or information required, unless the practitioner reasonably and in good faith believes the information is privileged and therefore not required to be disclosed. Communication between authorized tax practitioners and taxpayers regarding tax advice (see IRC § 7525) is generally confidential, and is treated in the same manner as communication between a taxpayer and an attorney: with respect to non-criminal tax matters involving the IRS, or non-criminal tax litigation brought by the United States in a federal court, or non-criminal tax litigation in which the United States is a defendant.

If communication involves promoting a company's direct or indirect participation in any tax avoidance scheme, the tax advice communication protection does not apply to any written communications between federal authorized tax practitioners and any persons (including company directors, shareholders, officers, employees, agents or representatives) in relation to tax advice communications.

230 Notice requires individuals to conduct due diligence when performing the following duties. Fill out or assist in filling out, approve and file tax returns, documents, declarations and other forms with the IRS. Determine the accuracy of any oral or written statements made to the Department of Treasury regarding IRS matters. Determine the accuracy of any oral or written statements made to clients regarding any matter under the jurisdiction of the IRS.

If reasonable care was taken in hiring, supervising, training and evaluating the individual and the nature of the relationship between the individual and the person was appropriately considered, then due diligence will be assumed to have been performed when relying on the work product of another.

Individuals bound by Notice 230 may not act as a witness, notarize documents, or perform any official acts in matters in which they have a personal interest, including as an advisor, attorney, or officer of, or any other capacity involving, the Internal Revenue Service.

Individuals bound by Notice 230 may not endorse or otherwise negotiate any check issued by the taxpayer to a client (including by transferring funds to any account held by or under the control of a professional or any entity related to a professional) for any federal tax liability.

Individuals subject to Notice 230 may be temporarily prohibited or terminated from practicing before the IRS, or be censured, because of misconduct or dishonorable conduct. In addition to any other disciplinary action, fines may be imposed on the individual and his or her company. The following list contains examples of dishonorable conduct. For other examples, see Notice 230, Section 10.51(a). Convicted of any criminal offense under the Internal Revenue Code or any offense involving dishonesty or breach of trust. Deliberately providing false or misleading information, or participating in such activity, in matters related to federal taxes. Engaging in prohibited solicitation of employment, as described in Notice 230, Section 10.30. Deliberately failing to file a federal tax return, evading or attempting to evade any federal tax or payment, or participating in such action. Misappropriating or failing to properly and timely remit funds received from a client for the purpose of paying United States taxes or other obligations. Attempting to influence the official conduct of IRS employees by means of threats, false accusations, coercion or intimidation, or by offering gifts, benefits or any other inducement. Being terminated or temporarily prohibited from practicing before the District of Columbia or any U.S. state, territory, possession, district, federal or any federal court, or any federal agency, organization or committee. Deliberately assisting and abetting another person in practicing before the IRS during a period of temporary prohibition, termination of qualification, or ineligibility. Using obscene language, making deliberate false or misleading statements, or transmitting or disseminating malicious or libelous content, or engaging in any contemptible conduct, in matters related to practicing before the IRS. Deliberately, recklessly, or by gross incompetence, providing false opinions; or providing incompetent opinions on federal tax issues.

If an individual is found to be incompetent or engaged in conduct that is detrimental to reputation, or has failed to comply with the regulations of Subsection B, or has intentionally and knowingly misled or threatened a client or prospective client for the purpose of fraud, the Secretary of the Treasury or his designee may, after notice and an opportunity for a hearing, revoke, suspend or terminate the individual's practice before the Internal Revenue Service under the notice of 230. A revocation is a public revocation. An individual under the notice of 230 includes any lawyer, certified public accountant, registered tax preparer, registered retirement plan counselor, or registered actuary who engages in activities representing a taxpayer or providing advice, as well as any individual who holds an annual tax season closing certificate and who engages in activities for the purpose of federal tax purposes, and any appraiser who engages in activities for the purpose of federal tax purposes to value assets.

The power of attorney is your written authorization to an individual to receive your confidential tax information from the IRS and to act on your behalf in a particular matter. If the authorization is unrestricted, the individual can generally do all the things you can do, except negotiate or endorse a check. Granting power of attorney to a registered retirement plan counselor, a registered actuary, or a tax return preparer who is not registered is limited. For information about the restrictions on annual filing season plan preparers with an Enrolled Retirement Plan Representative (ERP) certificate, see IRS procedure 2014-42 and IRS.gov/Tax-Professionals/Return-Preparers-Office-RPO-At-a-Glance (English).

Lawyers, Certified Public Accountants, and Registered Tax Preparers may engage in the following activities: 1. Represent you in any dealings with the IRS or its employees. 2. Sign agreements to extend the period of limitations for collection or assessment of taxes. 3. Sign agreements to waive the right to a refund or to claim a refund. 4. Sign agreements to transfer property.

The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) has a centralized computer data base system called the Centralized Authorization File System. This system contains information about the authority of persons representing taxpayers. Generally, when you file a power of attorney form with the IRS, this form will be processed to be included in the Centralized Authorization File System. Entering your power of attorney into the Centralized Authorization File System will enable IRS personnel who do not have a copy of your power of attorney to verify the authority of your representative by accessing the Centralized Authorization File System. If you designate that your representative should receive a copy of the notices and communications from the IRS, this will also enable the IRS to automatically send these communications to your representative. You can have your power of attorney entered into the Centralized Authorization File System by attaching it to a completed Form 2848 and filing it with the IRS. Your signature is not required; however, your representative must sign a representation statement (see Form 2848, Part 2).

IRS accepts copies of the power of attorney transmitted by fax (fax). If you choose to file the power of attorney by fax, make sure the IRS office that corresponds to your area is equipped to receive this type of transmission. Your representative can file the Form 2848 electronically through the IRS website. For more information, your representative can visit IRS.gov/eServices to learn more. If you are filing the Form 2848 for electronic signature authorization, do not file the Form 2848 with the IRS. Instead, give the form to your representative, who will keep the document.

Submit any updates or amendments to the existing power of attorney in writing. Your signature (or the signature of the person authorized to sign on your behalf) is a required field. To do so, submit the updated Form 2848 or non-IRS power of attorney to the IRS office where you filed the original version, along with the past or future tax return(s) for which the power of attorney is being used. If you specifically authorized your representative to replace or delegate authority to another representative, the authorized representative may replace or delegate authority. To do so, the representative must file the following items with the IRS office where the power of attorney was filed. 1. A written notice of replacement or delegation signed by the authorized representative. 2. A written representative statement from the new representative. 3. A copy of the power of attorney that specifically authorizes the replacement or delegation.

If you wish to revoke a previously signed power of attorney and do not wish to appoint a new representative, you must write 'Revoked' at the top of the first page of Form 2848 and add the current signature and date below the 'Revoked' notation. Then, you must mail or fax a copy of the power of attorney with the 'Revoked' notation to the IRS at the location shown on Form 2848, or if the power of attorney is for a specific matter, to the IRS office that handles that matter. If you do not have a copy of the power of attorney to revoke, you must send a statement of revocation to the IRS indicating that the power of attorney is being revoked, listing the matter and years/periods, and listing the name and address of the authorized representative whose power is being revoked. You must sign and date the statement of revocation. If you wish to revoke all authority, write 'Delete all years/periods' instead of listing specific matters and years/periods.

If your representative no longer wishes to act as a representative, he or she must write 'CANCELED' at the top of page 1 of Form 2848 and add the current signature and date below the notation. Then, he or she must provide a copy of the power of attorney with the notation to the IRS in the same manner as above by the taxpayer revoking. If your representative does not have a copy of the power of attorney that he or she wishes to cancel, he or she must send a statement of cancellation to the IRS indicating that the power of attorney granted has been canceled, listing the matters and years/periods, and listing the taxpayer's name, taxpayer identification number and address (if known). The representative must sign and date the statement. Student-held powers of attorney will be recorded in the centralized authorization file system for 130 days from the date of receipt. If you authorize a student to represent you after that time, you will need to submit another updated Form 2848.

For partnership tax years beginning after December 31, 2017, the Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act partnership audit and litigation procedures and rules applicable to elected large partnerships were repealed by the 2015 Bipartisan Budget Act and replaced by a new centralized partnership audit regime, and the term 'partnership representative' replaced the term 'tax matters partner'. Under Treasury Regulation 301.9100-22T, certain partnerships may elect to use the new regime for partnership tax returns for tax years beginning between November 2, 2015 and January 1, 2018.

If Form 2848 is not complete, the IRS will attempt to contact you or your representative by mail or telephone to confirm missing information. For example, if your signature or signature date is missing, the IRS will contact you. If the missing information involves your representative and the information on the form is sufficient to contact your representative (e.g., address and/or telephone number), the IRS will attempt to contact your representative. In either case, the power of attorney will not be considered valid until all necessary information is filled in on the form and the form is accepted by the IRS. Until the form is completely filled out and accepted by the IRS, the individual designated as representative will not be authorized to practice before the IRS on your behalf.

The IRS uses the most up-to-date encryption technology to ensure that your electronic filing is secure and reliable. You can file electronically by using the IRS2Go mobile app, by phone, or online at IRS.gov/Payments. Electronic filing is simple and quick, and it's faster than mailing a check or money order. Visit IRS.gov/Payments and use one of the following options to file. IRS Direct Pay: Pay your personal tax bill or estimated tax directly from your checking or savings account without paying extra fees. Debit or credit card: Choose an approved payment processor to file online, by phone, or on a mobile device. Electronic Funds Withdrawal: Only available when using tax preparation software or filing through a tax professional. Federal Electronic Tax Payment System: Best for businesses. You must register. Check or money order: Mail your payment to the address listed on your notice or instruction. Cash: You can pay your taxes in cash at participating retail stores.

We can help you resolve problems you can't solve with the IRS. And our services are free. If you are eligible for our help, you will be assigned a tax advocate who will work with you throughout the process and do everything possible to resolve your problems. In the following situations, the Taxpayer Advocate Service can help you: Your problem is causing you, your family, or your business financial hardship. You are facing (or your business is facing) an immediate threat of adverse action, or You have tried multiple times to contact the IRS, but no one responds, or the IRS does not respond within the promised time frame.

The Low Income Taxpayer Clinic (LITC) is separate from the IRS. The LITC represents individuals with income below a certain level who need to resolve tax problems with the IRS, such as audits, appeals, and tax disputes. In addition, the clinic can provide information about taxpayer rights and responsibilities in different languages for individuals whose second language is English. These services are provided free of charge or for a low fee. To find a clinic near you, visit TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov/LITCmap (English) or see IRS Publication 4134 — Low Income Taxpayer Clinic List (English) combined.

The fastest way to get your tax refund is to combine direct deposit and e-file with the IRS. Direct deposit can safely transfer your tax refund e-check to your financial account. Over 80% of taxpayers use direct deposit to get their tax refund. The IRS will issue over 90% of refunds in less than 21 days.

Due to changes in the law, the IRS cannot issue tax returns with the correct EITC or ACTC amounts before mid-February 2018. This applies to the entire refund amount, not just the amount of the benefit.

The IRS will not contact taxpayers via email or phone to request personal or financial information. This includes text messages and social media channels, as well as any other type of electronic communication. Visit IRS.gov/IDProtection for information and videos. If your Social Security number is lost or stolen, or you think you may be a victim of identity theft related to taxes, visit IRS.gov/ID to learn what steps to take.
